editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE ORDINARY, A Comedy, Written by WILLIAM CARTVVRIGHT, M. A. Ch. Ch. Oxon.
LONDON, Printed for Humphrey Moſeley, and are to be ſold at his ſhop at the Sign of the Princes Armes in St PAVLS Churchyard. 1651.

div.head: The PROLOGUE.
div.l: 'TWould wrong our Author to beſpeake your Eares;
Your Perſons he adores, but Judgement feares:
For where you pleaſe but to diſlike, he ſhall
Be Atheiſt thought, that worſhips not his Fall.
Next to not marking, 'tis his hope that you
Who can ſo ably judge, can pardon too.
His Converſation will not yet ſupply
Follies enough to make a Comedy;
He cannot write by th' Poll; nor Act we here
Scenes, which perhaps you ſhould ſee liv'd elſewhere;
No guilty line traduceth any; all
We now preſent is but conjecturall;
'Tis a meere gheſſe: Thoſe then will be too blame,
Who make that Perſon, which he meant but Name.
That web of Manners which the Stage requires,
That maſſe of Humors which Poetique Fires
Take in, and boyle, and purge, and try, and then
With ſublimated follies cheat thoſe men
That firſt did vent them, are not yet his Art,
But as drown'd Iſlands, or the World's fifth Part
Lye undiſcover'd; and he only knows
Enough to make himſelfe ridiculous.
Think then, if here you find nought can delight,
He hath not yet ſeen Vice enough to Write.

list.item:
Complices in the Ordinary.
Heare-ſay—An Intelligencer.
Slicer—A Lieutenant.
Meanewell, Littleworth diſguiz'd, a decay'd Knights Son.
Andrew—his Son, Suter to Mrs Jane.

Clubbers at the Ordinary.
Rimewell—A Poet.
Bag-ſhot.—A decay'd Clerke.
Sir Chriſtopher—A Curate.
Vicar Catchmey.—A Cathedrall Singingman.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: WE're made my Boys, we're made; me thinks I am
Growing into a thing that will be worſhip'd.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: I ſhall ſleep one day in my Chaine, and Skarlet
At Spittle-Sermon.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Were not my wit ſuch
I'd put out monies of being Maior.
But O this braine of mine! that's it that will
Barre me the City Honour.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: We're cry'd up
O'th' ſudden for the ſole Tutors of the Age.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Eſteem'd diſcreet, ſage, trainers up of youth.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Our houſe becomes a place of Viſit now.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: In my poore judgement 'tis as good my Lady
Should venture to commit her eldeſt ſonne
To us, as to the Inns of Court: hee'l be
Undone here only with leſſe Ceremony.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Speak for our credit my brave man of War.
What Meane-well, why ſo lumpiſh?

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: Pray y' be quiet.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Thou look'ſt as if thou plott'ſt the calling in
O'th' Declaration, or th' Aboliſhing
O'th' Common-Prayers; cheare up; ſay ſomething for us.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: Pray vexe me not.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: Theſe fooliſh puling ſighs
Are good for nothing, but to endanger Buttons.
Take heart of grace man.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: Fie y'are troubleſome.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Nay fare you well then Sir.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: My Father ſtill
Runs in my mind, meets all my thoughts, and doth
Mingle himſelfe in all my Cogitations,
Thus to ſee eager villaines drag along
Him, unto whom they crouch'd; to ſee him hal'd,
That ne'r knew what compulſion was, but when
His vertues did incite him to good deeds,
And keep my ſword dry—O unequall Nature!
Why was I made ſo patient as to view,
And not ſo ſtrong as to redeeme? why ſhould I
Dare to behold, and yet not dare to reſcue?
Had I been deſtitute of weapons, yet
Arm'd with the only name of Son, I might
Have outdone wonder. Naked Piety
Dares more than Fury well-appointed▪ Bloud
Being never better ſacrific'd, than when
It flowes to him that gave it. But alas,
The envy of my Fortune did allow
That only, which ſhe could not take away,
Compaſſion; that which was not in thoſe ſavage,
And knowing Beaſts; thoſe Engines of the Law,
The even kill as uncontroul'd, as that.
How doe I grieve, when I conſider from
What hands he ſuffer'd! hands that doe excuſe
Th' indulgent Priſon; ſhackles being here
A kind of Reſcue. Young man tis not well
To ſee thy aged Father thus confin'd,
Good, good old man; alas thou 'rt dead to me,
Dead to the world, and only living to
That which is more than death, thy miſery:
The Grave could be a comfort: And ſhall I—
O would this Soule of mine—But Death's the wiſh
Of him that feares; hee's lazie that would dye.
I'le live and ſee that thing of wealth, that worme
Bred out of ſplendid mucke; that Citizen
Like his owne ſully'd Wares throwne by into
Some unregarded corner, and my Piety
Shall be as famous as his Avarice;
His Son whom we have in our Tuition
Shall be the Subject of my good Revenge;
I'le count my ſelfe no child, till I have done
Something thats worth that name: my Braine ſhall be
Buſie in his undoing; and I will
Plot ruine with Religion; his diſgrace
Shall be my Zeales contrivement; and when this
Shall ſtile me Son againe, I hope 'twill be
Counted not wrong, but Duty. When that time
Shall give my Actions growth, I will caſt off
This brood of Vipers: and will ſhew that I
Doe hate the Poyſon, which I meanet' apply.

sp.speaker: Pot.
sp.l: NOw help good Heaven! 'tis ſuch an uncouth thing
To be a widow out of Term-time—I
Doe feele ſuch aguiſh Qualmes, and dumps and fits,
And ſhakings ſtill an end—I lately was
A wife I do confeſſe, but yet I had
No husband: he (alas) was dead to me
Even when he liv'd unto the world; I was
A widdow whiles he breath'd; his death did only
Make others know ſo much. But yet—

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: How now?
So melancholy ſweet?

sp.speaker: Pot.
sp.l: How could I chooſe
Being thou wert not here? the time is come,
Thou'lt be as good unto me as thy word?

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Nay, hang me if I er'e recant. You'l take me
Both wind and limb at th' venture, will you not?

sp.speaker: Pot.
sp.l: Ay good Chuck, every inch of thee, ſhe were
No true woman that would not.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: I muſt tell you
One thing, and yet I'm loth.

sp.speaker: Pot.
sp.l: I am thy Rib,
Thou muſt keep nothing from thy Rib, good Chuck;
Thy yoak-fellow muſt know all thy ſecrets.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Why then I'l tell you ſweet.

sp.speaker: Pot.
sp.l: Heaven defend!

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: 'Tis true.

sp.speaker: Pot.
sp.l: Now God forbid; and would you offer
T' undoe a widdow-woman ſo? I had
As leive the old Vintner were alive againe.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: I was not born with it I confeſſe; but lying
In Turky for Intelligence, the great Turk,
Somewhat ſuſpicious of me, leſt I might
Entice ſome o'th' Seraglio, did command
I ſhould be forthwith cut.

sp.speaker: Pot.
sp.l: A heathen deed
It was: none but an Infidel could have
The heart to do it.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Now you know the worſt
That you muſt truſt to, come lets to the Church.

sp.speaker: Pot.
sp.l: Good Mr Hear-ſay, Nature ne'r intended
One woman ſhould be joyned to another.
The holy bleſſing of all wedlock was
T'encreaſe and multiply, as Mr Chriſtopher
Did well obſerve laſt Sabbath. Ile not do
Any thing 'gainſt Gods word. I do releaſe you
Of all your promiſes, and that it may not
Be ſaid you loſt by loving me, take this.
Perhaps I may get you a contribution
O'th' women of the Pariſh, as I did
The broken-bellied-man the other day.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Seeing you needs will caſt me off▪ let me
Intreat this one thing of you that you would not
Make me your Table-talk, at the next Goſſiping.

sp.speaker: Pot.
sp.l: Indeed I pitty thee poor thing, or rather
I pitty thee poore nothing. Good Lieutenant
How doſt thou? Thou art mindfull of thy Promiſe?

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: What elſe my jolly wench?

sp.speaker: Pot.
sp.l: Good ſweet Lieutenant
Give me but leave to aske one Queſtion of you,
Art thou intire and ſound in all thy limbs?

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: To tell the very truth, ere now I've had
A ſpice o'th' Pox, or ſo; but now I am ſound
As any Bell (Hem) waſt not ſhrill my Girle, ha?

sp.speaker: Pot.
sp.l: I do not aske thee about theſe diſeaſes;
My queſtion is whether thou'ſt all thy parts.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: Faith I have loſt a joint or two; as none
Of our Profeſſion come off whole, unleſſe
The Generall, and ſome ſneaks.

sp.speaker: Pot.
sp.l: My meaning is
Whether that ſomething is not wanting that
Should write thee husband.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: Ne'r feare that my wench;
Doſt think the King would ſend me to the wars
Without I had my weapons? Eunuchs are not
Men of imploiment in theſe dayes; his Majeſty
Hath newly put me on a peece of ſervice;
And if I e're come off (which I doe feare
I ſhan't, the danger is ſo great) brave Widow
Wee'l to't and get Commanders.

sp.speaker: Potl.
sp.l: If you can
Leave me, I can leave you: there are other men
That won't refuſe a Fortune when 'tis proffer'd.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: Well, I muſt to his Majeſty, think on't;
So fare thee well. Thine to his very Death,
That is a Month or two perhaps, D. Slicer.

sp.speaker: Potl.
sp.l: Kind Maſter Shape, you are exceeding welcome.
Here hath bin Mr Hearſay, and Lieutenant

sp.speaker: Slicer:
sp.l: You may gheſſe at their buſineſſe, but
I hope you thinke me faithfull.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: I beleeve
The memory of your Husbands aſhes, which
Scarce yet are cold, extinguiſheth all flames
That tend to kindling any Love-fire: 'Tis
A vertue in you, which I muſt admire
That only you amongſt ſo many ſhould
Be the ſole Turtle of the Age.

sp.speaker: Potl.
sp.l: I doe
Beare him in memory I confeſſe; but when
I doe remember what your promiſe was
When he lay ſicke, it doth take ſomething from
The bitterneſſe of Sorrow. Woman was
Not made to be alone ſtill.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Tender things
At ſeventeen may uſe that plea; but you
Are now arriv'd at Matron: theſe young ſparkes
Are rak'd up, I preſume, in ſager Embers.

sp.speaker: Potl.
sp.l: Nay don't abuſe her that muſt be your Wife;
You might have pitty, & not come with your nicknames,
And call me Turtle: have I deſerv'd this?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: If that you once hold merits, I have done;
I'm glad I know what's your Religion.

sp.speaker: Potl.
sp.l: What's my Religion? 'tis well known there hath
Been no Religion in my houſe e'r ſince
My Husband dy'd.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: How now ſweet Shape? ſo cloſe
Alone w' your Widow.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Sirs dare you beleeve it?
This thing, whoſe prayer it hath been theſe ten
Yeares, that ſhe may obtaine the ſecond tooth,
And the third haire, now dotes on me, on me
That doe refuſe all that are paſt ſixteen.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: Why faith this was her ſute to me juſt now.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: I had the firſt on't then. A Coachman, or
A Groome were fitter far for her.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: You doe
Honour her too much to thinke ſhe deſerves
A thing that can luſt moderately, give her
The ſorrell Stallion in my Lords long ſtable.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Or the ſame colour'd Brother, which is worſe.

sp.speaker: Potl.
sp.l: Why Gentlemen—

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Foh, foh! ſhe hath let fly.

sp.speaker: Potl.
sp.l: Doe y' think I have no more manners than ſo?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Nay faith I can excuſe her for that: But
I muſt confeſſe ſhe ſpoke, which is all one.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: Her breath would rout an Army, ſooner than
That of a Cannon.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: It would lay a Devill
Sooner than all Trithemius charmes.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Heark how
It bluſters in her noſthrils like a wind
In a foule Chimney.

sp.speaker: Potl.
sp.l: Out you baſe companions,
You ſtinking Swabbers.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: For her gate, that's ſuch,
As if her noſe did ſtrive t'outrun her heels.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: She's juſt ſix yards behind, when that appears;
It ſaves an Uſher Madam.

sp.speaker: Pot.
sp.l: You are all
Moſt foul-mouth'd knaves to uſe a woman thus.

sp.speaker: Sli.
sp.l: Your playſter'd face doth drop againſt moiſt weather.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Fie, how you writh it; now it looks juſt like
A ruffled boot.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: Or an oyld paper Lanthorn.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Her noſe the candle in the midſt of it.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: How bright it flames? Put out your noſe good Lady
Your burn day-light.

sp.speaker: Pot.
sp.l: Come up you lowſie Raskals.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Not upon you for a Kingdom good Joane,
The great Turk, Joane—the great Turk.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: Kiſſe him Chuck,
Kiſſe him Chuck open'd mouth'd and be reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Pot.
sp.l: Hang you baſe cheating Varlet.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: Don't you ſee
December in her face?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Sure the Surveyer
Of the high-waies will have to do with her
For not keeping her countenance paſſable.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: There lies a hoare froſt on her head, and yet
A conſtant thaw in her noſe.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: She's like a peece
Of fire-wood, dropping at one end, and yet
Burning i'th' midſt.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: O that endeavouring face!
When will your coſtiveneſſe have done good Madam?

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Do you not heare her Guts already ſqueake
Like Kitſtrings?

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: They muſt come to that within
This two or three yeares; by that time ſhee'l be
True perfect Cat: They practiſe before hand.

sp.speaker: Pot.
sp.l: I can endure no longer, though I ſhould
Throw off my womanhood.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: No need, that's done
Already: nothing left thee, that may ſtile thee
Woman but Luſt, and Tongue; no fleſh but what
The vices of the ſex exact, to keep them
In heart.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Thou art ſo leane and out of caſe
That 'twere abſurd to call thee Devill incarnate.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: Th'art a dry Devill troubled with the luſt
Of that thou haſt not, fleſh.

sp.speaker: Pot.
sp.l: Rogue, Raskall, Villaine,
Ile ſhew your cheating tricks I faith: all ſhall
Be now laid open. Have I ſuffer'd you
Thus long i' my houſe, and ne'r demanded yet
One penny rent, for this? Ile have it all,
By this good bleſſed light I will.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: You may
If that you pleaſe undo your ſelf, you may.
I will not ſtrive to hinder you. There is
Something contriving for you, which may be
Perhaps yet brought about, a Match or ſo;
A proper fellow; 'tis a trifle, that;
A thing you care not for I know. Have I
Plotted to take you off from theſe to match you
In better ſort, and am us'd thus? As for
The Rent you aske, here take it, take your money;
Fill, choake your gaping throat. But if as yet
You are not deaf to counſell, let me tell you
It had been better that you ne'r had took
It may ſtop ſome proceedings.

sp.speaker: Pot.
sp.l: Mr Hearſay,
You know you may have even my heart out of
My belly (as they ſay) if you'l but take
The paines to reach it out; I am ſometimes
Peeviſh I doe confeſſe; here take your money.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Potl.
sp.l: Good Sir.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: No, keep it and hoord it up.
My purſe is no ſafe place for it.

sp.speaker: Potl.
sp.l: Let me
Requeſt you that you would be pleas'd to take it.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Alas 'twould only trouble me; I can
As willingly goe light, as be your Treaſurer.

sp.speaker: Potl.
sp.l: Good Mr Slicer ſpeake to him to take it,
Sweet Mr Shape, joyne with him.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: Nay, be once
O'rerul'd by a woman.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Come, come, you ſhall take it.

sp.speaker: Potl.
sp.l: Nay Faith you ſhall; here put it up good Sir.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Upon intreaty I'm content for once;
But make no Cuſtome of't; you doe preſume
Upon my eaſie fooliſhneſſe; 'tis that
Makes you ſo bold: were it another man
He ne'r would have to doe with you. But marke me,
If e'r I find you in this mood againe,
I'le daſh your hopes of Marriage for ever.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: GOd ſave you Tutors both.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: Fie Andrew, fie;
What kiſſe your hand? you ſmell, not complement.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Beſides, you come too near when you ſalute.
Your breath may be diſcover'd; and you give
Advantage unto him you thus accoaſt
To ſhake you by the hand, which often doth
Endanger the whole arme. Your Gallant's like
The Chryſtall glaſſe, brittle; rude handling crackes him.
To be ſaluted ſo were to be wounded.
His parts would fall aſunder like unto
Spilt Quickſilver; an Eare, an Eye, a Noſe
Would drop like Summer fruit from ſhaken Trees.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: For the ſame reaſon I'd not have you dance.
Some Courtiers, I confeſſe, doe uſe it; but
They are the ſounder ſort, thoſe fooliſh ones
That have a care of health, which you ſhall not
If you'l be rul'd by me. The hazard's great,
'Tis an adventure, an exploit, a piece
Of ſervice for a Gentleman to caper.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: A Gallant's like a Leg of Mutton, boyl'd
By a Spaniſh Cooke; take him but by the one End
And ſhake him, all the fleſh fals from the bones,
And leaves them bare immediately.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: I would
Not be a leg of Mutton here.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: I ſaw
In France a Monſieur, only in the Cutting
Of one croſſe Caper, Riſe a man, and come
Downe, to th' amazement of the ſtanders by,
A true extemporary Skeleton;
And was ſtrait read on.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Sure this man,
Good Tutor, was quite rotten.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: See how you
Betray your breeding now! quite rotten! 'tis
Rottenneſſe perhaps in Footmen, or in Yeomen,
'Tis tenderneſſe in Gentlemen; They are
A little over-boyl'd, or ſo.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: He is
A Churle, a Hind, that's wholeſome; ſome raw thing
That ne're was at London: One in whom
The Clown is too predominant. Refin'd
People feele Naples in their bodies; and
An Ach i'th' bones at Sixteen, paſſeth now
For high diſſent; it argues a great birth.
Low blouds are never worthy ſuch infection.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Ay, but my Father bid me I ſhould live honeſt,
And ſay my Prayers, that he did.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: If that
You cannot ſleep at any time, we do
Allow you to begin your Prayers, that ſo
A ſlumber may ſeize on you.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: But as for
Your living honoſt, 'twere to take away
A trade i'th' Common-wealth; the Surgeons
Benefit would go down: you may go on
In fooliſh chaſtity, eate only Sallads,
Walk an unskilfull thing, and be to learn
Something the firſt night of your wife; but that's
To marry out of faſhion.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Here's no Proofes,
No Doctrines, nor no Uſes. Tutor I
Would fain learn ſome Religion.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Religion?
Yes to become a Martyr, and be pictur'd
With a long Labell out o' your mouth, like thoſe
In Foxes Book; juſt like a Jugler drawing
Ribband out of his throat.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I muſt be gone.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: Obedience is the firſt ſtep unto ſcience;
Stay and be wiſe.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Indeed I dare not ſtay
The Glyſter works you ſent to purge groſs humors.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: Being you will not take your Lecture out
Good morrow to y' good Andrew. This ſoft foole
Muſt ſwim in's Fathers wealth. It is a curſe
That Fortune juſtly makes the City's lot,
The young Fool ſpends what e're the old Knave got.

div.head: ACT. I. SCEN. IV.
div.stage: To Hearſay, enter Slicer and Credulous.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: SIr let me tell you this is not the leaſt
Of things wherein your wiſedome ſhewes it ſelf,
In that you've plac'd your Son in this good ſort.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: Nay nay, let me alone to give him breeding;
I did not hold the Univerſity▪
Fit for the training up of ſuch a Spirit.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: The Univerſity? 't had been the only way
T' have took him off his courage, and his mettal,
He had return'd as Slaves doe from the Gallies,
A naked ſhorn thing with a thin dockt top,
Learnedly cut into a Logick mode.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: A private Oath given him at firſt Entrance
Had ſworn him Pilgrim unto Conventicles;
Engag'd him to the hate of all, but what
Pleaſeth the ſtubborn froward Elect.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: But we
Following another Modell doe allow
Freedome and courage, cheriſh and maintaine
High noble thoughts—

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Set nature free, and are
Chymiſts of manners—

sp.speaker: Sli.
sp.l: Do inſtruct of States—

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: And Wars: there's one, look on him—

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: Doe but view
That ſearching Head—

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: The very ſoule of Battell,
True ſteele.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: H' hath been an Agent ſome few years
(A ſcore or ſo) for Princes, and as yet
Doth not write forty.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: I confeſſe I can
Diſcover th' Entrailes of a State perhaps,
Lay open a Kingdoms Paunches, ſhew the bowels
And inwards of a Seigniory or two;
But for your deeds of Valour, there is one,
Although I ſpeak it to his face, that can
Write a Geography by his own Conqueſts.
H' hath fought o'r Strabo, Ptolomy and Stafford;
Travell'd as far in arms, as Lithgoe naked.
Born weapons whither Coriat durſt not
Carry a ſhirt or ſhooes. Jack Mandevil
Ne'r ſaild ſo far as he hath ſteerd by Land;
Uſing his Colours both for maſt and ſaile.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: I'd thought h' had been Leiutenant.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: That's all one.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: I've worn ſome Leather out abroad; let out
A heathen Soul or two; fed this good ſword
With the black bloud of Pagan Chriſtians;
Converted a few Infidels with it.
But let that paſſe. That man of peace there hath
Been truſted with Kings Breaſts—

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: His name is heard
Like Thunder, and that meer word, Slicer, hath
Sufficed unto victory.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: He's cloſe,
Reſerv'd, lock'd up. The ſecrets of the King
Of Tartary, of China, and ſome other
Counſels of moment have been ſo long kept
In's body without vent, that every morning
Before he covers them with ſome warme thing
Or other you may ſmell 'em very ſtrongly;
Diſtinguiſh each of them by ſeverall ſents—

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: A grove of Pikes are ruſhes to him, hail
More frights you, than a ſhower of Bullets him—

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: The Dutch come up like broken beer; the Iriſh
Savour of Uſquebaugh; the Spaniſh they
Smell like unto perfume at firſt, but then
After a while end in a fatall ſteame—

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: One Drum's his Table, the other is his Muſick.
His Sword's his Knife, his Colours are his Napkins▪
Carves nouriſhing Horſe, as he is us'd to do
The hoſtile Paguim, or we veniſon: Eates
Gunpowder with his meat inſtead of Pepper,
Then drinks o'r all his Bandeleers, and fights—

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: Secrets are rank'd and order'd in his belly,
Juſt like Tobacco leaves laid in a ſweat.
Here lies a row of Indian ſecrets, then
Something of 's own on them; on that another
Of China Counſels, cover'd with a lidd
Of New-found-land diſcoveries; next, a bed
Of Ruſſia Policies, on them a lay
Of Preſter-Johnion whiſpers—

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Slights a tempeſt;
Counts lightning but a giving fire, and thunder
The loud report when heaven hath diſcharg'd.
H' hath with his breath ſupplyed a breach.
When he's once fixt no Engine can remove him.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: 'Twould be a Policy worth hatching, to
Have him diſſected, if 'twere not too cruell.
All ſtates would lye as open as his bowels.
Turkey in's bloudy Liver; Italy
Be found in's reines; Spaine buſie in his Stomack;
Venice would float in's Bladder; Holland ſaile
Up and down all his veines; Bavaria lie
Cloſe in ſome little gut, and Ragioni
Di Stato generally reek in all.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: I ſee my Son's too happy; he is born
To be ſome man of Action, ſome Engine
For th' overthrow of Kingdomes.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Troth he may
Divert the Torrent of the Turkiſh rule
Into ſome other Tract; damme up the ſtreame
Of that vaſt headlong Monarchy, if that
He want not meanes to compaſſe his intents.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: The Turkiſh Monarchy's a thing too big
For him to mannage; he may make perhaps
The Governour of ſome new little Iſland,
And there plant Faith and Zeale: But for the preſent
M'ambition's only to contrive a Match
Between Sir Thomas Bite-figg's only Daughter,
And (if I may ſo call him now) my Son;
'Twill raiſe his Fortunes ſomewhat.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: We have got
One that will doe more good with's tongue that way
Than that uxorious ſhowre that came from Heaven,
But you muſt oyle it firſt.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: I underſtand you
Greaze him i'th'fiſt you meane: there's juſt ten Peeces,
'Tis but an earneſt: If he bring't about,
I'le make thoſe then a hundred.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Thinke it done.

div.head: ACT. I. SCEN. V.
div.l: OUr life methinks is but the ſame with others;
To couzen, and be couzen'd, makes the Age.
The Prey and Feeder are that Civill thing
That Sager heads call Body Politick.
Here is the only difference; others cheat
By ſtatute, but we do't upon no grounds.
The fraud's the ſame in both, there only wants
Allowance to our way: the Common-wealth
Hath not declar'd her ſelf as yet for us;
Wherefore our Policy muſt be our Charter.

sp.speaker: Mea.
sp.l: Well mannag'd Knav'ry is but one degree
Below plaine Honeſty.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: Give me villany
That's circumſpect, and well advis'd, that doth
Colour at leaſt for goodneſſe. If the Cloake
And Mantle were pull'd off from things, 'twould be
As hard to meet an honeſt Action as
A liberall Alderman, or a Court Nun.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Knowing then how we muſt direct our ſteps,
Let us chalk out our paths; you, Shape, know yours.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Where e'r I light on Fortune, my Commiſſion
Will hold to take her up: I'l eaſe my ſilken
Friends of that idle luggage, we call Money.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: For my good toothleſſe Counteſſe, let us try
To win that old Emerit thing, that like
An Image in a German clock, doth move,
Not walke, I meane that rotten Antiquary.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: Hee'i ſurely love her, 'cauſe ſhe looks like ſome
Old ruin'd peece, that was five Ages backward.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: To the great Veſtry wit, the Livery braine,
My Common-Councell Pate, that doth determine
A City buſineſſe with his gloves on's head,
We muſt apply good hope of wealth and meanes.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: That griping Knight Sir Thomas muſt be call'd
With the ſame lure: he knows t' a crum how much
Loſſe is in twenty dozen of Bread, between
That which is broke by th' hand, and that is cut.
Which way beſt keeps his Candles, bran or ſtraw.
What tallow's loſt in putting of 'm out
By ſpittle, what by foot, what by the puffe,
What by the holding downwards, and what by
The extinguiſher; which week will longeſt be
In lighting, which ſpend faſteſt; he muſt heare
Nothing but Moyties, and Lives, and Farmes,
Coppies, and Tenures▪ he is deaf to th'reſt.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: I'l ſpeak the language of the wealthy to him.
My mouth ſhall ſwill with Bags, Revenues, Fees,
Eſtates, Reverſions, Incomes, and aſſurance.
He's in the Gin already, for his Daughter
Shee'l be an eaſie purchaſe.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: I do hope
We ſhall grow famous; have all ſorts repaire
As duly to us, as the barren Wives
Of aged Citizens do to St Antholins.
Come let us take our Quarters: we may come
To be ſome great Officers in time,
And with a reverend Magiſterial frown,
Paſſe ſentence on thoſe faults that are our own.

div.head: ACT. II. SCENE I.
div.stage: Have-at-all, Slicer, Hearſay, having reſcued him in a Quarrell.

sp.speaker: Have:
sp.l: 'TIs deſtin'd, I'l be valiant, I am ſure
I ſhall be beaten with more credit then,
Than now I do eſcape. Lieutenant haſt
Bethought thy ſelf as yet? haſt any way
To make my Sword fetch bloud?

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: You never yet
Did kill your man then?

sp.speaker: Have.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Nor get your Wench
With child I warrant?

sp.speaker: Have.
sp.l: O Sir.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: You're not quite
Free of the Gentry till y'have marrd one man
And made another: when one fury hath
Cryd quit with t'other, and your Luſt repair'd
What Anger hath deſtroyd, the Titles yours,
Till then you do but ſtand for't.

sp.speaker: Have.
sp.l: Pox! who'd be
That vile ſcorn'd Name, that ſtuffs all Court-gate Bils?
Lieutenant thou mayſt teach me valour yet.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: Teach thee? I will inſpire thee man. I'l make
Thy name become a terrour, and to ſay
That Have-at-all is comming, ſhall make roome
As when the Bears are in Proceſſion.
Heark hither Franks—

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: That's good, but—

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: How think'ſt now?

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Nay he will pay you large—lie.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Pay, what elſe?

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Make him beleeve the Citizen's his Gueſt.
The Citizen that he is his.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: Concluded;
Would you fight fair or conquer by a ſpell?

sp.speaker: Have.
sp.l: I do not care for Witchcraft; I would have
My ſtrength relie meerlie upon it ſelf.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: There is a way that I ne'r ſhew'd it yet,
But to one Spaniard, and 'twas wondrous happy.

sp.speaker: Have.
sp.l: Think me a ſecond Spaniard worthy Sir.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: Then liſten. The deſign is by a dinner;
An eaſie way you'l ſay, I'l ſay a true;
Hunger may break ſtone walls, it ne'r hurts men.
Your cleanly feeder is your man of valour.
What makes the Peaſant grovel in his muck,
Humbling his crooked ſoule, but that he eates
Bread juſt in colour like it? Courage ne'r
Vouchſaf'd to dwell a minute, where a ſullen
Pair of brown loaves darken'd the durty Table;
Shadows of bread, not bread. You never knew
A ſolemn Son of Bagpudding and Pottage
Make a Commander; or a Tripe-eater
Become a Tyrant: he's the Kingdoms arm
That can feed large, and choicely.

sp.speaker: Have.
sp.l: If that be
The way, I'l eat my ſelf into courage,
And will devour valour enough quickly.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: 'Tis not the caſual eating of thoſe meats,
That doth procure thoſe Spirits, but the order,
And manner of the meal; the ranking of
The diſhes, that does all; elſe he that hath
The greateſt range would be the hardeſt man.
Thoſe goodly Juments of the Guard would fight
(As they eat Beef) after ſix ſtone a day;
The Spit would nouriſh great Attempts: my Lord
Would lead a Troop, as well as now a Maſque;
And force the Enemies ſword with as much eaſe
As his Miſtriſſes Bodkin: Gallants would
Owe valour to their Ordinaries, and fight
After a crown a meal.

sp.speaker: Have.
sp.l: I do conceive
The Art is all in all. If that you'l give
A bill of your directions, I'l account
My ſelf oblig'd unto you for my ſafety.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: Take it then thus. All muſt be Souldier-like;
No diſh but muſt preſent Artilery.
Some military inſtrument in each.
Imprimis ſixe or ſeven yards of Tripe
Diſplay'd inſtead o'th' Enſign.

sp.speaker: Have.
sp.l: Why, you ſaid,
Tripe-eaters ne'r made Tyrants.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: Peace Sir, Learners
Muſt be attentive and beleeve. Do y' think
Wee'l eat this? 'tis but for formalitie;
Item a Coller of good large fat Brawn
Serv'd for a Drum, waited upon by two
Fair long black Puddings lying by for drumſticks;
Item a well grown Lamprey for a Fife;
Next ſome good curious Marchpanes made into
The form of Trumpets: Then in order ſhall
Follow the Officers. The Captain firſt
Shall be preſented in a warlike Cock,
Swiming in whitebroth▪ as he's wont in bloud;
The Sergeant Major he may buſtle in
The ſhape of ſome large Turkey; For my ſelf,
Who am Leiutenant, I'm content there be
A Buſtard only; let the Corporall
Come ſweating in a Breaſt of Mutton, ſtuff'd
With Pudding, or ſtrut in ſome aged Carpe,
Either doth ſerve I think. As for Perdues
Some choice Sous'd-fiſh brought couchant in a diſh
Among ſome fennell, or ſome other graſſe,
Shews how they lie i'th' field. The Souldier then
May be thus rank'd. The common one Chicken,
Duck, Rabbet, Pidgeon. For the more Gentile,
Snipe, Woodcock, Partridge, Pheaſant, Quail will ſerve.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Bravelie contriv'd.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: That weapons be not wanting
Wee'l have a dozen of bones well charg'd with marrow
For Ordnance, Muskets, Petronels, Petarrs;
Twelve yards of Sauſage by inſteed of Match;
And Caveari then prepar'd for wild-fire.

sp.speaker: Hea
sp.l: Rare Rogue! how I do love him now me thinks.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: Next wee'l have true fat, eatable old Pikes;
Then a freſh Turbut brought in for a Buckler,
With a long Spitchcock for the ſword adjoyn'd;
Wee'l bring the ancient weapons into play.

sp.speaker: Have.
sp.l: Moſt rare by heaven.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: Peaches, Apricocks,
And Malecotoons, with other choiſer Plums
Will ſerve for large ſiz'd Bullets; then a diſh
Or two of Peaſe for ſmall ones. I could now
Tell you of Pepper in the ſtead of Powder,
But that 'tis not in faſhion 'mongſt us Gallants;
If this might all ſtand upon Drum heads, 'twould
Work ſomewhat better.

sp.speaker: Have.
sp.l: Wil't ſo? then we'l have 'em
From every ward i'th' City.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: No I'm loath
To put you to ſuch charge: for once, a long
Table ſhall ſerve the turn; 'tis no great matter.
The main thing's ſtill behind: we muſt have there
Some Fort to ſcale; a veniſon paſtie doth it:
You may have other Pies inſtead of outworks;
Some Sconces would not be amiſſe, I think.
When this is all prepar'd, and when we ſee
The Table look like a pitch'd Battel, then
Wee'l give the word, Fall too, ſlaſh, kill, and ſpoile;
Deſtruction, rapine, violence, ſpare none.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Thou haſt forgotten Wine, Lieutenant, wine.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: Then to avoid the groſſe abſurdity
Of a dry Battel, cauſe there muſt ſome bloud
Be ſpilt (on th' enemies ſide I mean) you may
Have there a Rundlet of brisk Claret, and
As much of Aligant, the ſame quantitie
Of Tent would not be wanting, 'tis a wine
Moſt like to bloud. Some ſhal bleed fainter colours,
As Sack, and White wine. Some that have the itch
(As there are Taylors ſtill in every Army)
Shall run with Reniſh, that hath Brimſtone in't.
When this is done fight boldly; write your ſelf
The tenth or 'leventh Worthy, which you pleaſe,
Your choice is free.

sp.speaker: Have.
sp.l: I'l be the gaming Worthy;
My word ſhall be Twice twelve; I think the dice
Ne'r mounted any upon horſeback yet.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: Wee'l bring your friends & ours to this large dinner:
It works the better eaten before witneſſe.
Beware you ſay 'tis yours: Confeſſion is
One ſtep to weakneſſe, private Conſcience is
A Theater to valour. Let's be cloſe.
Old Credulous, and his Son, and Mr Caſter
Shall all be there.

sp.speaker: Have.
sp.l: But then they will grow valiant
All at my charge.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: Ne'r fear't; th'unknowing man
Eates only Fleſh, the underſtanding Valour;
His ignorance i'th' myſtery keeps him coward:
To him 'tis but a Meale; to you 'tis vertue.
It ſhall be kept here.

sp.speaker: Hav.
sp.l: No fitter place; there is
An old rich Clutchfiſt Knight, Sir Thomas Bitefig,
Invite him too; perhaps I may have luck,
And break his Purſe yet open for one hundred.
A Uſurer is ſomewhat exorable
When he is full: He ne'r lends money empty.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: Diſcreet, and wiſely done; I was about
T' have prompted it.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Stout Mr Haveatall
Lets be ſworn Brothers.

sp.speaker: Have.
sp.l: Pox! thou fear'ſt Ile beat thee
After I've eaten. Doſt thou think I'l offer't?
By my next meale I won't: nay I do love
My friends how e'r: I do but think how I
Shall baſtinado o'r the Ordinaries.
Arm'd with my ſword, Battoone and foot Ile walk
To give each rank its due. No one ſhall ſcape,
But he I win off.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: You ſhall have at leaſt
Some twenty warrants ſerv'd upon you ſtraight;
The trunck-hoſe Juſtices will try all means
To bind you to the Peace, but that your ſtrength
Shall not be bound by any.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: Surgeons will
Pray for your health and happineſſe, you may
Bring 'em to be your Tributaries, if
You but denie to fight a while.

sp.speaker: Have.
sp.l: My teeth
Are on an edge till I do eat; now will
I couzen all men without oppoſition.
I feel my ſtrength encreaſe with very thought on't.
Sword, ſword, thou ſhalt grow fat; and thou Battoon
Hold out I prethee, when my labour's done,
I'l plant thee in the Tower-yard, and there
Water'd with wine thou ſhalt revive, and ſpring
In ſpight of Nature with freſh ſucculent boughs,
Which ſhall ſupply the Commonwealth with Cudgels.
Thou I firſt meet after this meal I do
Pronounce unhappy ſhadow; happie yet
In that thou'lt fall by me. Some men I will
Speak into Carcaſſe, Some I'l look to death,
Others I'l breath to duſt, none ſhall hold back
This fatall Arm: The Templers ſhall not dare
T'attempt a reſcue; no mild words ſhall bury
My ſplitted ſpitchcock'd—

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: Oliv'd, haſht—

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Dri'd, powder'd.

sp.speaker: Have.
sp.l: Roſted fury.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: IF what I ſpeak prove falſs, then ſtigmatize me.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: I nas not what you mean; Depardieux you
Snyb mine old years, Sans fail I wene you bin
A Jangler, and a Golierdis.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: I ſwear
By theſe two Janus heads you had of us,
And your own too, as reverend as theſe,
There is one loves you that you think not on.

sp.speaker: Mot.
sp.l: Nad be, none pleaſaunce is me ylaft,
This white top writeth my much years, I wis
My fire yreken is in Aſhen cold,
I can no whit of daliance: If I kiſſen
Theſe thick ſtark briſtles of mine beard will pricken
Ylike the skin of Hownd-fiſh. Sikerly
What wends againſt the grains is lytherly.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: Me thinks y'are ſtrong enough and very luſty,
Fit to get heyres; among your other peeces
Of age and time, let one young face be ſeen
May call you Father.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Wholſom counſel! but
The world is now full Tykel ſykerly;
'Tis hard to find a Damoſel unwenned;
They being all Coltiſh and full of Ragery,
And full of gergon as is a flecken Pye.
Who ſo with them maketh that bond anon
Which men do clypen ſpouſaile, or wedlock,
Saint Idiot is his Lord I wis.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: This is
No tender and wanton thing, ſhe is a ſtay'd
And ſetled widow, one who'l be a Nurſe
Unto you in your latter daies.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: A Norice
Some dele yſtept in age! ſo mote I gone
This goeth aright, how highteth ſhe ſay you?

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: Mrs Joane Potluck, Vintner Potluck's widow.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Joane Potluck Spinſter. Lore me o thing mere
Alouten, what time gan ſhe brendle thus?

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: On Thurſday morning laſt.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Y' bleſſed Thurſday,
Ycliped ſo from Thor the Saxons God.
Ah benedicite I might ſoothly ſayne,
Mine mouth hath itched all this livelong day
All night me met eke, that I was at Kirke;
My heart gan quapp full oft. Dan Cupido
Sure ſent thylke ſweven to mine head.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: You ſhall
Know more if you'l walk in.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Wend you before me,
Cembeth thy ſelf, and pyketh now thy ſelf;
Sleeketh thy ſelf; make cheere much Digne good Robert:
I do arret thou ſhalt acquainted bin
With Nymphs and Fawny, and Hamadryades;
And yeke the ſiſterne nine Pierides
That were tranſmued into Birds, nemp'd Pyes,
Metamorphoſers, wat well what I mean.
Tis is as Jollie now as fiſh in Seine.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: CAn I lie hid no where ſecurely from
The throng, and preſſe of men? muſt every place
Become a Theater, where I ſeek ſhelter?
And ſolitudes become markets, 'cauſe I'm there?
Good Sir, I know your tricks: you would intrap;
This is your ſnare, not your requeſt.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Take heed,
He's nois'd about for a deep ſearching head:
Ile pawn my life 'tis a trick.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Leave off theſe Ginnes,
You do not do it handſomly; you think
Y'have met with fooles I warrant.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: On my life
A ſpie, a meere informer.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: As I hope
For fortunes, my intentions are moſt faire.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: A Gameſters Oath: he hath ſome reſervation.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Yet did I think you true—

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: By all that's good,
You do me wrong to think, that I'd wrong you.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: VVhen I lay Agent laſt in new Atlantis
I met with what you now deſire, a ſtrange
New way of winning, but yet very ſure.
Were not the danger great I'd—

sp.speaker: Cast.
sp.l: Do you think
I will betray my ſelf, or you, whom I
Eſteeme above my ſelf? I have as yet
One hundred left; ſome part of which—

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Faith Sir,
Theſe times require advice; if it ſhould come
Unto the Councels eare once, he might be
Sent into other Kingdoms, to win up
Monies for the relief o'th' State, and ſo
Be as it were an honeſt kind of Exile.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: If I do e'r diſcover may I want
Monie to pay my Ordinary, may I
At my laſt ſtake (when there is nothing elſe
To loſe the game) throw Ames Ace thrice together.
Ile give you forty pound in hand—

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: I may
Shew you the vertue of 't, though not the thing;
I love my Country very well. Your high
And low men are but trifles: your poyz'd Dye
That's ballaſted with Quickſilver or Gold
Is groſſe to this—

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Profer him more I ſay.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Here's fifty—

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: For the briſtle Dye it is
Not worth that hand that guides it; toies fit only
For Clerks to win poore Coſtermongers ware with.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: You do not come on well.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Here's threeſcore—

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Then
Your hollowed thumb join'd with your wriggled box,
The ſlur, and ſuch like are not to be talk'd of;
They're open to the eye. For Cards you may
Without the help of any ſecret word,
Or a falſe hand, without the cut or ſhuffle,
Or the packt trick, have what you will your ſelf;
There's none to contradict you.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: If you pleaſe
But to inſtruct me here is foureſcore pound.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Do y' think 'tis money I eſteeme? I can
Command each Terme, by Art as much as will
Furniſh a Navy. Had you but five pound
Left you in all the world, I'd undertake
Within one fortnight you ſhould ſee five thouſand.
Not that I covet any of your droſſe,
But that the power of this Art may be
More demonſtrably evident, leave in
My hands all but ſome ſmaller ſum to ſet,
Something to ſtake at firſt.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Hee'l tell you all
If you but ſeem to truſt him.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Here I'l lay
Down in your hands all but this little portion,
VVhich I reſerve for a Foundation.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Being y'are confident of me, and I
Preſume your lips are ſealed up to ſilence,
Take that, which I did never yet diſcover;
So help you Fortune, me Philoſophie.
(I muſt entreat your abſence Mr Shape.)
I do preſume you know the ſtrength and pow'r
That lies in Phancie.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Strange things are done by it.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: It works upon that which is not as yet.
The little Aethiop Infant had not been
Black in his Cradle, had he not been firſt
Black in the Mothers ſtrong Imagination.
'Tis thought the hairie Child that's ſhewn about
Came by the Mothers thinking on the Picture
Of Saint Iohn Baptist in his Camels Coat.
See we not Beaſts conceive, as they do fanſie
The preſent colours plac'd before their Eyes?
VVe owe pyed Colts unto the varied horſecloth;
And the white Partridge to the neighbouring ſnow.
Fancie can ſave or kill; it hath clos' up
VVounds when the Balſam could not, and without
The aid of ſalves; to think hath been a cure.
For VVitchcraft then, thats's all done by the force
Of meer Imagination. That which can
Alter the courſe of Nature, I preſume
You'l grant ſhall bear more rule in petty hazzards.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: It muſt, it muſt, good Sir I pray go on.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: Now the ſtrong'ſt fancies ſtill are found to dwel
In the moſt ſimple; they being eaſieſt won
To the moſt firm beliefe, who underſtand not
VVho 'tis they do believe. If they think 'twill
Be ſo, it will be ſo; they do command,
And check the courſe of Fortune; they may ſtop
Thunder, and make it ſtand, as if arreſted,
In its mid journey: If that ſuch a one
Shall think you'l win, you muſt win; 'tis a due
That nature paies thoſe men in recompence
Of her deficiency, that what e'r they think
Shall come to paſſe. But now the hardeſt will be
To find out one that's capable of thinking.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: I know you can produce an Inſtrument
To work this your deſign by. Let me owe you
The whole and entire courteſie.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: I've one
Committed to my cuſtody but lately,
The powerfull'ſt that way, I e'r found yet;
He will but think he ſhall b' abus'd in ſuch
A Company, and he's abus'd; he will
Imagine only that he ſhall be cheated,
And he is cheated: All ſtill comes to paſſe.
He's but one pin above a Natural: But—

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Wee'l purchaſe him; I'l take up for't; old Simon
Shall have my Farme outright now: what's a peece
Of durty Earth to me? a clod? a turf?

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Becauſe I ſee your freer nature's ſuch,
As doth deſerve ſupplies, I'l do my beſt
To win him or a while into your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: If I ſhould ſtrive to pay you thanks, I ſhould
But undervalue this great courteſie.
Sir, give me leave to think & worſhip. Stay;
Firſt will I beggar all the Gentlemen
That do keep Termes; then build with what I win.
Next I'l undo all gaming Citizens,
And purchaſe upon that: the Foreman ſhall
Want of his wonted opportunities,
Old Thomas ſhall keep home I warrant him.
I will aſcend to the Groom Porters next.
Flie higher Games, and make my mincing Knights
Walk muſing in their knotty Freeze abroad;
For they ſhall have no home. There ſhall not be
That pleaſure that I'l baulk: I'l run o'r Nature;
And when I've ranſack'd her, I'l weary Art;
My means I'm ſure will reach it. Let me ſee
'Twill yearly be—By Heav'n I know not what—

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Ne'r think to ſum it, 'tis impoſſible;
You ſhall ne'r know what Angels, Peeces, Pounds,
Theſe names of want and beggary mean; your tongue
Shall utter nought but millions: you ſhall meaſure,
Not count your moneys; your revenews ſhall
Be proud and inſolent, and unruly;
They ſhall encreaſe above your conquer'd ſpendings
In ſpight of their exceſſe; your care ſhall be
Only to tame your riches, and to make them
Grow ſober, and obedient to your uſe.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: I'l ſend ſome forty thouſand unto Pauls;
Build a Cathedral next in Banbury;
Give Organs to each Pariſh in the Kingdom;
And ſo root out the unmuſicall Elect.
I'l pay all Souldiers whom their Captaines won't;
Raiſe a new Hoſpitall for thoſe maim'd People
That have been hurt in gaming; Then build up
All Colleges, that Ruine hath demoliſh'd,
Or, interruption left unperfect.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: 'Twil
Never be done I think, unleſs you do it.
Provide the wealthieſt Gameſters, there's but one
Thing that can do us wrong, Diſcovery.
You have no enemie, but frailty.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Night
And ſilence are loud names, compar'd with me.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: I ſee the tide of Fortune rowling in
Without reſiſtance. Go, be cloſe, and happy.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: VPon my Conſcience now he cheated me;
I could have never loſt it elſe ſo ſtrangely.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: What is a paltry cloak to a man of worth?
It barr'd men only o'th' ſight of your body:
Your handſomneſſe will now appear the better.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: He was as like our Mr Shape, as could be;
But that he had a patch upon his Cheek,
And a black beard, I ſhould have ſworn 'twere he:
It was ſome body in his cloaths I'm ſure.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: Some cunning Cheater upon my life won
His cloak and ſuit too.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: There it is for certain.
Pies take him, doth he play for cloaks ſtill? Surely
He hath a Fly only to win good cloaths.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: The Pox and Plague take all ill fortune! this
The ſecond time that he hath cheated me:
My very beſt ſuit that I had!

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: How now?
What loſt your cloak, and ſuit? A jeſt I vow;
I vow a pretty jeſt: 'odsnigs I gueſs'd ſo;
I ſaw him have it on; it made him look as like you,
As like you—'Tis a Rogue, a meer Decoy.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: A Rogue, a meer Decoy? and yet like me?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Nay hold, I mean he is a Rogue, when that
He hath his own cloaths on. D'y' think that I
Would call him ſo, when he is in your ſuit?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: No more of that good Andrew, as you love me
Keep in your wit.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Speak Tutor, do I uſe
To quarrell? ſpeak good Tutor.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: That wit Andrew
Of yours will be th' undoing of you, if
You uſe't no better.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Faith I thought I might
Have broke a witty jeſt upon him, being
I've loſt my cloak.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: True, but he has loſt his too:
And then you know that is not lawfull wit.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Here's Mr Credulous, and old Sir Thomas,
They have ſome buſineſſe with you.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: Bring 'em in.

sp.speaker: Sha
sp.l: My buſineſſe lies not here Sirs, fare you well.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: For Gods ſake don't you tell old Sim on't now.

div.head: ACT II. SCEN. V.
div.stage: To them, Sir Thomas Bitefig, Credulous.

sp.speaker: Mea.
sp.l: GOd ſave you good Sir Thomas.

sp.speaker: Sr Tho.
sp.l: Save you Sir.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: You'r welcome Mr Credulous.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: Come hither;
Whither do you ſteal now? what? where's your cloak?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Going to foiles ev'n now, I put it off.

sp.speaker: Mea.
sp.l: To tell you truth he hath loſt it at Doublets.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: With what a lie you'd flap me in the mouth?
Thou haſt the readieſt invention
To put off any thing—thou hadſt it from
Thy mother I'l be ſworn; 'tnere came from me.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: Peace as you love your ſelf; if that the Knight
Should once perceive that he were given to gaming,
'Twould make him break the match off preſently.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: Sr Thomas here's my Son; he may be yours,
If you pleaſe to accept him.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Father don't
Give me away for this: try me once more.

sp.speaker: Sr Tho.
sp.l: I like his perſon well enough, if that
You'l make him an Eſtate convenient.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: He hath more in him Sir than he can ſhew;
He hath one fault, he's ſomething covetous.

sp.speaker: Sr Tho.
sp.l: Mary a very commendable fault.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: He is deſcended of no great high bloud:
He hath a Houſe, although he came of none.
His Grandfather was a good Livery man,
Paid ſcot and lot, old Timothy Credulous
My Father, though I ſay it that ſhould not.

sp.speaker: Sr Tho.
sp.l: I don't regard this thing, that you call bloud:
'Tis a meer name, a ſound.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: Your Worſhip ſpeaks
Juſt like your ſelf; me thinks he's noble,
That's truely rich: men may talk much of Lines,
Of Arms, of Bloud, of Race, of Pedigree,
Houſes, Deſcents, and Families; they are
But empty noiſe God knows, the idle breath
Of that puff nothing Honour; Formall words,
Fit for the tongues of men that ne'r knew yet
What Stem, what Gentry, nay, what vertue lies
In great Revenues.

sp.speaker: Sr Tho.
sp.l: Well and pithy ſaid,
You may work on my Daughter, and prevaile,
For that yong ſtripling: 'Tis a fooliſh wench,
An unexperienc'd Girle, ſhe'd like to have been
Caught by Sir Robert Littleworths Son, if that
I had not baniſh'd him my houſe: a youth
Honeſt enough I think, but that he's poor;
Born to more Name than Fortune.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: He is ſafe
For ever wooing. I have laid his Father
Out of harm's way; there's picking meat for him:
And God knows where he's gon; he hath not been
Seen this long while; he's ſure turn'd vagabond;
No ſight of him ſince th' Arreſt of his Father.
Andrew addreſſe your ſelf too good Sir Thomas.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: 'Slid Father you're the ſtrangeſt man— I won't.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: As God ſhall mend me thou'rt the proudeſt thing—
Thou canſt not complement, but in Capariſons.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: What's that to you? I'd fain ſay ſomething yet;
But that I can't my loſſes do ſo vex me.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: Come think not on't my Boy, I'l furniſh thee.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Sir, though—

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: Nay, to't I ſay; help him Sir, help him.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Sir, though without my cloak at this time—
To morrow I ſhall have one—give me leave
Barely to ſay—I am your ſervant Sir—
In hoſe and doublet.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: I'l do what you told me.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Take heed: if that you do't hee'l gueſſe you'r giv'n
To idle ſpendings, and ſo croſſe the match.
I will invite him as to my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: Do ſo.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Sir Thomas, if you'l pleaſe ſo far to grace us,
As be a gueſt to morrow here, we ſhall
Study hereafter to deſerve the favour.

sp.speaker: Sr Tho.
sp.l: Although I do not uſe to eat at Ord'naries,
Yet to accept your courteſie, good friends,
I'l break my wonted cuſtome.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: You ſhall have it
With a free heart.

sp.speaker: Sr Tho.
sp.l: If I thought otherwiſe,
I do aſſure you, I'd not venture hither.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: HArrow alas! I ſwelt here as I go;
Brenning in fire of little Cupido.
I no where hoart yfeele, but on mine head.
Huh. huh, huh, ſo; ycapred very wele.
I am thine Leeke, thou Chaucer eloquent;
Mine head is white, but o mine taile is green.
This is the Palyes where mine Lady wendeth
Saint Francis, and Saint Benedight,
Bleſſe this houſe from wicked wight,
From the Night-mare and the Goblin,
That is hight good fellow Robin.
Keep it from all evill Spirits,
Fayries, Weezels, Rats and Ferrets,
From Curfew time
To the next prime.
Come forth mine Duck, mine Bryd, mine honycomb.
Come forth mine Cinamon.

sp.speaker: Pot.
sp.l: Who is't that cals?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: A Knight moſt Gent.

sp.speaker: Pot.
sp.l: What is your pleaſure Sir?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Thou art mine pleaſure, by dame Venus brent;
So freſh thou art, and therewith ſo lycand.

sp.speaker: Pot.
sp.l: Alas! I am not any flickering thing:
I cannot boaſt of that ſlight-fading gift
You men call beauty; all my handſomneſſe
Is my good breeding, and my honeſty.
I could plant red, where you now yellow ſee;
But painting ſhews an harlot.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: Harlot, ſo
Called from one Harlotha Concubine
To deignous Wilhelme, hight the Conqueror.

sp.speaker: Pot.
sp.l: Were he ten Williams, and ten Conquerors
I'd have him know't, I ſcorn to be his Harlot.
I never yet did take preſſe-money to
Serve under any one.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: Then take it now.
Werme kiſſe! Thine lips ytaſte like marrow milk;
Me thinketh that freſh butter runneth on them.
I grant well now, I do enduren woe,
As ſharp as doth the Titius in Hell,
Whoſe ſtomack fowles do tyren ever more,
That highten Vultures, as do tellen Clerkes.

sp.speaker: Pot.
sp.l: You've ſpoke my meaning, though I do not know
What 'tis you ſaid. Now ſee the fortune on't;
We do know one anothers Souls already;
The other muſt needs follow. Where's your dwelling?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Ycloſe by Alderſgate there dwelleth one
Wights clypen Robert Moth; now Alderſgate
Is hotten ſo from one that Aldrich hight;
Or elſe of Elders, that is, ancient men;
Or elſe of Aldern trees which growden there;
Or elſe as Heralds ſay, from Aluredus:
But whence ſo e'r this Yate ycalled is
There dwelleth Robert Moth thine Paramour.

sp.speaker: Pot.
sp.l: Can you be conſtant unto me as I
Can be to you?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: By Woden God of Saxons,
From whence comes Wenſday, that is Wodenſday,
Truth is a thing that ever I will keep,
Unto thylke in which I creep into
My Sepulchre; I'l be as faithfull to thee,
As Chaunticleere to Madam Partelot.

sp.speaker: Pot.
sp.l: Here then I give away my heart to you,
As true a heart as ever widow gave.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: I Robert Moth, this tenth of our King
Give to thee Joan Potluck my biggeſt crumpe Ring▪
And with it my Carcaſſe entire I bequeathen
Under my foot to Hell, above my head to heaven:
And to witneſſe that this is ſooth,
I bite thy red lip with my tooth.

sp.speaker: Pot.
sp.l: Though for a while our bodies now muſt part,
I hope they will be joyn'd hereafter.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: O!
And muſt we part? alas, and muſt we ſo?
Sin it may be no bet, now gang in peace.
Though ſoft into mine bed I gin to ſink
To ſleep long as I'm wont to done, yet all
Will be for naught; I may well lig and wink,
But ſleep ſhall there none in this heart yſink.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: SO now the Morgage is mine own outright;
I ſwear by the faith of my Body now
It is a pretty thing, o' my corporal Oath
A very pretty thing. Beſides the houſe,
Orchards, and Gardens: ſome two hundred Acres
Of Land that beareth as good Country corn,
For Country corn, as may be.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: As I'd have it.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: How now good friend ! where doſt thou live? doſt thou
Know Caſter's Farme?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Yes Sir; I fear 'tis gon:
Sure Caſter's Farme is caſt away.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: A jeſt!
Good troth a good one of a Country one;
I ſee there's wit there too. Then thou doſt know it.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: I am affraid I ſhall not know it long;
I ſhall loſe my acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: 'Snigs another!
A very perillous head, a dangerous brain.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: God bleſſe my Maſter, and the Devil take
Some body elſe.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: Um! that's not quite ſo good
As th' other two; that ſome body elſe is me:
(Now you ſhall ſee how hee'l abuſe me here
To mine own face) why ſome Body elſe good Brother?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: The rich gout rot his bones; an hungry, old,
Hard griping Citizen, that only feeds
On Heyrs and Orphans goods, they ſay muſt have it:
One that ne'r had the wiſdom to be honeſt;
And's therefore Knave, 'cauſe 'tis the eaſier Art.
I know he hath not given half the worth on't.
'Tis a meer cheat.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: 'Slid Brother thou haſt paid him
To th' utmoſt, though he hath not paid thy Maſter.
Now is my wit up too: this Land I ſee
Will make men thrive i'th' brain.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Would he were here,
Who e'r he be, I'd give him ſomewhat more
Into the bargain: a baſe thin-jaw'd ſneaksbill
Thus to work Gallants out of all. It grieves me
That my poor Tenement too goes into th' ſale.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: What have I done? now wit deliver me.
If he know I am he, hee'l cut my throat;
I never ſhall enjoy it: ſure it was
Your Maſters ſeeking friend; he would ne'r elſe
Have had to doe with it; he that bought it is
A very honeſt man; and if you pleaſe him
Will deale with you. I may ſpeak a word
In your behalf: 'twont be the worſe for you.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I'm going Sir unto him; do you know
Where I may find him?

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: What if I am he?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I am afraid he is not half ſo honeſt
As you do ſeem.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: Faith I'm the ſame; I try'd
What metal thou waſt made of: I perceive
Thou wilt not flinch for th' wetting; thou mayſt be
My Bayliff there perhaps.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: And 't pleaſe your Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: So now the caſe is alter'd.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I do know
It was my Maſters ſeeking, you would ne'r
Have had to do with 't elſe. He ſent me to you
For the laſt hundred pound, by the ſame token,
That you invited him to th' eating houſe.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: (O this ſimplicity! he does not know
Yet what an Ordnary means.) I was now coming
To have paid it in.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: I'l ſave your Worſhip that
Labour an't pleaſe you: let me now begin
My Bayliffeſhip.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: 'Snigs wiſer yet than ſoe.
Where is thy Maſter?

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: Sir, my Maſter's here
I thank my ſtars; but Mr Caſter is
At an Horſe-race ſome ten miles off.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: VVhy then
I'l ſtay till he returns; 'twill be by dinner.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Your beſt way's now to ſend it; if by chance
The race go on his ſide, your VVorſhip may
Faile of your purchaſe.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: 'Snigs and that's conſiderable.
Here, here, make haſte with it; but e'r thou goeſt
Tell me, is't a pretty thing?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: O' my corporall Oath,
A very pretty thing: beſides the houſe
Orchards, and Gardens, Some two hundred Acres
Of Land that beareth as good Country Corne,
God give you luck on't.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: Right as I did ſay,
Ev'n word by word. But prethee ſtay a little;
VVhat Meadow ground's there? Paſture in proportion?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: As you would wiſh Sir; I'm in haſte.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: Nay Bayliffe
But one word more, and I have done; what place
Is there to dry wet linnen in?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: O twenty
To hang up cloaths, or any thing you pleaſe.
Your VVorſhip cannot want line-room. God be wi' you.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: But this once and—

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I muſt be gone—The Race.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: Little thinkſt thee how diligent thou art
To little purpoſe. 'Snigs I pitty him;
VVhat haſte he makes to cheat himſelf! poor foole!
Now I am ſafe the wretch muſt pardon me
For his poor Tenement; all's mine. I'l ſow
One ground or other every month with Peaſe:
And ſo I will have green ones all the year.
Theſe Yeomen have no Policie i'th'world.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.l: PRay y' entertain your ſelf a while, untill
I give my Miſtris notice of your preſence.
I'd leave a book with you, but that I ſee
You are a Gentleman: perhaps you'l find
Some pretty ſtories in the hangings there.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: Thank you ſweet-heart.

sp.speaker: Priſc.
sp.l: (A very proper man)
If't lye in me to doe you any pleaſure,
Pray you Sir uſe me, you ſhall find me ready.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.l: I make no doubt of that: theſe Implements,
Theſe chamber Properties are ſuch ripe things,
They'l fall with the leaſt touch. From twelve to twenty
They thinke that others are to ſue to them;
When once they've paſt theſe limits, they make bold
I cannot ſay to wooe, that's ſomthing modeſt,
But aske downright themſelves.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: Leave us Priſcilla,
And wait without awhile.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: Faire Miſtres pardon
The boldneſſe of a ſtranger, who uncivilly
Thus interrupts your better thoughts.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: May I
Demand your buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: Under favour thus.
Not to uſe farther circumſtance faire Virgin,
(And yet leſſe faire 'cauſe Virgin) you are one
That are the thought, the care, the aime, the ſtrife,
I ſhould not erre if I ſhould ſay the madneſſe
Of all young men; all ſighs, all folded Armes,
All o'r-caſt looks, all broken ſleeps are ow'd
Only to you.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: I'm ſorry I ſhould be
A trouble unto any: if I could
Afford the remedy as well as now
I doe your grief, aſſure your ſelfe that cure
Shall be the birth of my next Action.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: That cure is my requeſt. If that this were
Mine own ſute, I had us'd no circumſtance.
Young Maſter Credulous a proper man
(For ſure he ſhall be rich) one whom the whole
Liſt of our City-Virgins dote on—you
Conceive the reſt I know.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: Alas, what ailes him?
I'l not be ſlack to doe him any good.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: 'Tis in your power. He is very much
If you will know't—But ſure you will not grant
If I ſhould tell you—

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: If you thus preſume
That I am hard, you only aske denyall:
Your expectations croſs'd except you faile.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: If you will know it then, he is in love.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: I pitty him indeed poore heart: with whom?

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: Even with your beautious ſelf.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: 'Tis not well done
To ſcoffe one ne'r did injure you.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: I vow
By all that's good, by your faire ſelfe, I am
As tender of you as that bleſt one is
Who e'r he be that loves you moſt. If I
In any caſe abuſe you, let me be
More miſerable than Little-worth.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: Is he become expreſſion? is his Fate
The period of ill wiſhes? ſure he never
Deſerv'd ſo ill from you.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: I don't reflect
Upon his ruin'd Fortunes, but your coldneſſe.
And ſure I may call him unhappy, whom
You doe neglect.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: That man, where ere he be,
Is happier than your ſelfe; and were he here,
You ſhould ſee him receiv'd and your ſelf ſcorn'd.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: I doe not thinke ſo Lady; ſure you would
Make more of me than ſo. I'l bring the man,
And ſo confute you.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: It may be I might
Love you the better ſomthing for that Office,
If he might enter here.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: Nay I could tell
Y'had caſt him off: alas you need not hide it,
I have it from himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: Doth he think ſo?
Could I but ſee him—

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: If his ſight can bring
But the leaſt joy unto you (as perhaps
You'l take ſome pleaſure in his miſery)
You ſhall enjoy it.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: I doe feare you promiſe
Only to raiſe my hopes a while, and then
To triumph in their Ruine.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: That you may
See how my breaſt and tongue agree, I'l leave
This Ring with you till I return again.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: My Littleworth! foole that I was: could I
Not all this while perceive 'twas thee? why didſt thou
Deferre my joy thus long by ſuffering me
To ſtand i'th' Cloud?

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: Alas! I gheſs'd I'd been
Infectious to thee now; that thou wouldſt look
On a diſeaſe more mildly than on me:
For Poverty is counted a contagion.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: I call this kiſſe to witneſſe (which I wiſh
If I prove falſe may be the laſt to me
Which friends pay dying friends) I ne'r will be
Others than thine.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: I like the vow ſo well,
That the ſame way I'l ſeale my promiſe too.
If I prove not as thou (that is moſt conſtant)
May this kiſſe be, that I may wiſh it worſe,
Than that which is due to departing ſouls▪
The laſt that I ſhall take from thee. I am
Sen there, but yet unknown to them that ſend me,
To be anothers Spokes-man. The man is
That fooliſh Son of Mr Credulous:
Thou muſt pretend ſome liking▪ 'twas thy Father
Granted me this acceſſe to win thee for him;
Be thou no way averſe. 'T ſhall be my care
So to bring things about, that thou ſhalt be
Mine by conſent in ſpight of miſery.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: Be ſecret, and Love proſper thy deſign.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: Happy that man that meets ſuch faithfulneſſe.
I did not think it had been in the Sex.
I know not now what's miſery. Peace: my Fair
Is hallowing the Lute with her bleſt touch.

lg.l: COme, o come, I brook no ſtay:
He doth not love that can delay▪
See how the ſtealing Night
Hath blotted out the Light,
And Tapers do ſupply the Day.
To be chaſte is to be old,
And that fooliſh Girle that's cold
Is fourſcore at fifteen:
Deſires do write us green,
And looſer flames our youth unfold.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: 'T cannot be her, her voice was ne'r prophan'd
With ſuch immodeſt numbers.

lg.l: See the firſt Taper's almoſt gone,
Thy flame like that will ſtraight be none;
And I as it expire
Not able to hold fire.
She loſeth time that lies alone.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: 'Tis the breath
Of ſomething troubled with Virginity.

lg.l: O let us cheriſh then theſe Powr's
Whiles we yet may call them ours:
Then we beſt ſpend our time,
When no dull zealous Chime,
But ſprightfull kiſſes ſtrike the Hours.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: What doſt thou mean?

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.l: Only to pleaſe you Sir.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: Sweeteſt of things was't thou? Ifaith I gueſs'd
'Twould be no others melody but yours.
There have been many of your ſex much given
Unto this kind of muſick.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.l: Sappho was
Excellent at it: but Amphion he
He was the man that out-did all; 'tis ſaid
Of him, that he could draw ſtones with the ſound
Of his ſweet ſtrings. I'd willingly arrive
At ſome perfection in the Quality.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: I do acknowledge your deſires moſt prone.
This for your trouble.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: I am not mercenary,
Your acceptation is reward enough.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: You have it then.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.l: Beauty go with you Sir.

div.head: ACT. III. SCEN. IV.
div.stage: Credulous, Hearſay, Slicer, to them Sir Thomas Bitefig, Haveatall, Caſter, as to the Ordinary.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: YOur welcome friends, as I may ſay—

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: You do forget.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: — That am a gueſt as well as you.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: Moſt noble ſons of Fortune, and of Valour,
You grace us with your preſence: you muſt pardon
Our ſmall proviſion.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: No variety here
But you moſt noble gueſts, whoſe gracious looks
Muſt make a diſh or two become a feaſt.

sp.speaker: Have.
sp.l: I'l be as free as 'twere mine own.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Who thinks
On any thing that borders upon ſadneſſe
May he ne'r know what's mirth, but when others
Laugh at his ſullen wrinkles.

sp.speaker: Have.
sp.l: We will raiſe
A noiſe enough to wake an Alderman,
Or a caſt Captaine, when the reck'ning is
About to pay.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: Hang thinking, 'snigs I'l be
As merry as a Piſmire; come let's in.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: Let's march in order military Sirs.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: That's well remember'd moſt compleat Lieutenant

div.head: ACT III. SCEN. V.
div.stage: Rime-well, Bagſhot, Vicar Catchmey, Sir Chriſtopher.

sp.speaker: Rim.
sp.l: COme my moſt noble order of the club.
'Cauſe none will elſe, let's make much of our ſelves.
His letter may procure a Dinner yet.

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.l: Cheer up Sir Kit, thou lookſt too ſpiritually:
ſee too much of the Tith-pig in thee.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: I'm not ſo happy: Kit's as hungry now
As a beſieged City, and as dry
As a Dutch Commentator. This vile world
Ne'r thinks of Qualities: good truth I think
'T hath much to anſwer for. Thy Poetry
Rimewell, and thy voice Vicar Catchmey, and
Thy Law too Bagſhot is contemn'd: 'tis pitty
Profeſſions ſhould be ſlighted thus. The day
Will come perhaps, when that the Commonwealth
May need ſuch men as we. There was a time
When Coblers were made Church-men, and thoſe black'd
Smutch'd Creatures thruſt into white Surpliſſes,
Look'd like ſo many Magpies, and did ſpeak
Juſt as they, by rote. But now the Land
Surfets forſooth. Poor Labourers in Divinity
Can't earn their groat a day, unleſſe it be
Reading of the Chriſtian buriall for the dead:
When they ev'n for that reaſon truly thank
God for thus taking this their Brother to him.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.l: Something profane Sir Chriſtopher.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.l: When I
Levell my larger thoughts unto the Baſis
Of thy deep ſhallowneſs, am I prophane?
Henceforth I'l ſpeak, or rather not ſpeak, for
I will ſpeak darkly.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.l: There's one comfort then
You will be brief.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.l: My briefneſs is prolix;
Thy mind is bodily, thy ſoul corporeal;
And all thy ſubtile faculties are not ſubtile,
Thy ſubtilty is dulneſs. I am ſtrong.
I will not be conceiv'd by ſuch Mechanicks.

sp.speaker: Rime.
sp.l: I do conceive you though Sir Chriſtopher,
My Muſe doth ſometimes take the ſelfſame flight.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.l: Pauci, pauci ques aequus amavit.
But Quadrageſſimall wits, and fancies leane
As ember weeks (which therefore I call leane,
Becauſe they're fat) theſe I do doom unto
A knowing ignorance; he that's conceiv'd
By ſuch is not conceiv'd; ſenſe is non-ſenſe
If underſtood by them. I'm ſtrong again.

sp.speaker: Rime.
sp.l: You err moſt Orthodoxly ſweet Sir Kit.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.l: I love that though I hate it: and I have
A kind of diſagreeing conſent to't.
I'm ſtrong, I'm ſtrong again. Let's keep theſe two
In deſperate hope of underſtanding us.
Ridles, and Clouds are very lights of ſpeech:
I'l vaile my careleſſe anxious thoughts, as 'twere
In a perſpicuous cloud, that I may
Whiſper in a loud voice, and ev'n be filent
When I do utter words; words did I call them?
My words ſhall be no words, my voice no voice;
My noiſe no noiſe, my very language ſilence.
I'm ſtrong, I'm ſtrong: good Sir you underſtand not.

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.l: Nor do deſire; 'tis meerly froth, and barme,
The yeſt that makes your thin ſmall Sermons work.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.l: Thou hold'ſt thy peace moſt vocally. Again.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.l: I hate this Bilke.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.l: Thou loveſt 'cauſe thou doſt hate.
Thy injuries are Courteſies. Strong again.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Good Sampſon uſe not this your Aſſes jaw-bone.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.l: Thou'ſt got my love by loſing it; that earneſt
Jeſt hath regain'd my ſoul. Sampſon was ſtrong;
He kill'd a thouſand with an Aſſes-jawbone.
sp.stage: Ent. a Serv. as paſſing by
sp.l: And ſo will I. 'ſt, 'ſt—good friend d'y'hear?
Here is a letter friend to Mr Meanwell.

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.l: Any Reverſions yet? nothing tranſmiſs'd?

sp.speaker: Rime.
sp.l: No gleanings James? no Trencher Analects?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Parly a little with your ſtomacks Sirs.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.l: There's nothing ſo ridiculous as the hungry:
A faſting man is a good jeſt at any time.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: There is a Gentleman without, that will'd me
To ask if you'l admit of him among you,
He can't endure to be in good company.

sp.speaker: Catc.
sp.l: You'r merry James; yes by all means good James;
Admit quoth he? what elſe? pray y'ſend him in.
Let's be reſolv'd to fail out, now then he
Shall have the glory to compoſe the Quarrel,
By a good dozen of pacificall Beere.

sp.speaker: Rime.
sp.l: Bag. Agreed, agreed.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.l: My Coat allows no Quarrell.

sp.speaker: Rime.
sp.l: The Colour bears't if you'l venture the ſtuffe,
The tenderneſſe of it I do confeſſe
Some what denies a grapling.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.l: I will try,
Perhaps my Spirit will ſuggeſt ſome anger.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Save you boon ſparks: wil't pleaſe you to admit me?

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.l: Your Worſhip graceth us in condeſcending
To levell thus your preſence humble Sir.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: What may I call your name moſt reverend Sir?

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.l: His name's Sir Kit.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.l: My name is not ſo ſhort,
'Tis a triſſyliable, an't pleaſe your Worſhip:
But vulgar tongues have made bold to profane it
With the ſhort ſound of that unhallowed Idoll
They call a Kit. Boy learn more reverence.

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.l: Yes, to my Betters.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Nay friends, do not quarrel.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.l: It is the holy cauſe, and I muſt quarrell.
Thou Son of Parchment, got between the Standiſh
And the ſtiff Buckram bag: thou that maiſt call
The Pen thy Father, and the inke thy Mother,
The ſand thy Brother, and the wax thy Siſter,
And the good Pillory thy Couzen remov'd,
I ſay learn reverence to thy Betters.

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.l: Set up an hour-glaſſe; hee'l go on untill
The laſt ſand make his Period.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.l: 'Tis my cuſtome,
I do approve the Calumny: the words
I do acknowledge, but not the diſgrace.
Thou vile ingroſſer of unchriſtian deeds.

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.l: Good Iſrael Inſpiration hold your tongue;
It makes far better Muſick, when you Noſe
Sternolds, or Wiſdoms Meeter.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.l: By your leave
You fall on me now Brother.

sp.speaker: Rim.
sp.l: 'Tis my cauſe,
You are too forward Brother Catchm.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.l: I
Too forward?

sp.speaker: Rim.
sp.l: Yes I ſay you are too forward
By the length of your London meaſure Beard.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.l: Thou never couldſt entreat that reſpite yet
Of thy diſhoneſty as to get one hair
To teſtifie thy Age.

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.l: I'm beardleſſe too;
I hope you think not ſo of me?

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.l: Yes verily,
Not one hairs difference 'twixt you both.

sp.speaker: Rim.
sp.l: Thou violent Cuſhion-thumper, hold thy tongue,
The Furies dwell in it.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.l: Peace good Sir Kit.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.l: Sir Kit again? Thou art a Lopez; when
One of thy legs rots off (which will be ſhortly)
Thou'lt beare about a Quire of wicked Paper,
Defil'd with ſanctified Rithmes,
And Idols in the frontiſepiece: that I
May ſpeak to thy capacity, thou'lt be
A Balladmonger.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.l: I ſhall live to ſee thee
Stand in a Play-houſe doore with thy long box,
Thy half-crown Library, and cry ſmall Books.
By a good godly Sermon Gentlemen—
A judgment ſhewn upon a Knot of Drunkards—
A pill to purge out Popery—The life
And death of Katherin Stubs—

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.l: Thou wilt viſit windows;
Me thinks I hear thee with thy begging tone
About the break of day waking the Brethren
Out of their morning Revelations.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Brave ſport Ifaith.

sp.speaker: Rime.
sp.l: Pray y'good Sir reconcile them.
If that ſome Juſtice be i'th' Ordinary now
Hee'l bind them to the peace for troubling him.

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.l: Why ſhould he not good Sir, it is his office,

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Now 'tis o'this ſide; o for a pair of Cudgels!

sp.speaker: Rime.
sp.l: Peace Inkhorn, there's no muſick in thy tongue.

sp.speaker: Catc.
sp.l: Thou and thy Rime lye both; the tongue of man
Is born to muſick naturally.

sp.speaker: Rime.
sp.l: Thou thing,
