Thy belly looks like to ſome ſtrutting hill,
O'r ſhadow'd with thy rough beard like a wood.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.l: Or like a larger Jug, that ſome men call
A Bellarmine, but we a Conſcience;
Whereon the lewder hand of Pagan workman
Over the proud ambitious head hath carv'd
An Idoll large with beard Epiſcopal,
Making the Veſſel look like Tyrant Eglon.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.l: Prophane again Sir Chriſtopher I take it.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.l: Muſt I be ſtrong again? thou humane beaſt,
Who'rt only eloquent when thou ſayſt nothing,
And appear'ſt handſome while thou hid'ſt thy ſelf,
I'm holy 'cauſe prophane.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Couragious Raskals,
Brave Spirits, Souldiers in their daies I warrant.

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.l: Born in the field I do aſſure your Worſhip:
This Quarrelling is meant and drink to them.

sp.speaker: Rime.
sp.l: Thou lyeſt. Bag. Nay then I do defie thee thus.

div.stage: [Ba. draws his Inkhorn and Ri. catcheth off Sr Chr. hat and ſpectacles.]

sp.speaker: Rime.
sp.l: And thus I am prepar'd to anſwer thee.

sp.speaker: Ch.
sp.l: For the good Sts. ſake part them; I am blind,
If that my Spectacles ſhould once miſcarry.

sp.speaker: Rime.
sp.l: Caytiff, this holy inſtrument ſhall quaile thee.

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.l: And this ſhall ſend thee to thy couzen furies.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.l: I feel a film come o'r mine eyes already,
I muſt look out an Animal conductive,
I mean a Dog.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Pray y'beat not out his eyes in
Anothers hands.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.l: Moſt ſtrongly urg'd.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.l: Your words
Are meerly wind. James ho! what James! ſome beer.
They're maſtive Dogs, they won't be parted Sir,
Without good ſtore of Liquor.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: I will ſouce them.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Drink t' 'em Sir, if that you'l have 'em quiet.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Is that the way? here's to you my friends; a whole one.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Were't not for that good Gentleman thou'dſt ſmoak for't.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Had I not vow'd ſome reverence to his preſence.
Thou hadſt been nothing.

sp.speaker: Bag.
sp.l: 'Fore Mars I was dry:
This valour's thirſty: fill to my Antagoniſt.

sp.speaker: Rime.
sp.l: No, mine own diſh will ſerve: I'm ſingular.
Few veſſels ſtill do well; I carry this
To drink my beer, while others drink their ſack.
I am abſtemious Rimewel: I hate wine
Since I ſpake treaſon laſt i'th' Celler. Here
Give me thy hand, thou child of fervency.
Didſt thou miſtruſt thy ſpectacles?
It was no anger, 'twas a Rapture meerly.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.l: Drink, and excuſe it after. James your help.
Come Man of voice keep time while that I drink.
This moiſture ſhall dry up all injuries,
Which I'l remember only to forget;
And ſo hereafter, which I'm wont to call
The future now, I'l love thee ſtubbornly.
Your beer is like my words, ſtrong, ſtinging geare.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.l: Here little Lawyer, let's be friends hereafter;
I love this reconcilement with my heart.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: 'Tis the beſt deed that e'r I did: O my conſcience
I ſhall make a good Juſtice of the Peace,
There had been bloud-ſhed, if I had not ſtickled.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: More bloud been ſpilt I warrant than beer now.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: That Inkhorn is a deadly dangerous weapon:
It hath undone one quarter of the Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Chriſ.
sp.l: Men ſhould forgive; but thou art far, yea far
From it O Bagſhot; thou'rt in love with hate;
Bleſſe me! I ſee the Fiend ſtill in his looks;
He is not reconcilable with drink;
Hee'l never love truly, till he eat with me.
The nature of his Spirit asketh meat:
He hath a Woolf in's breaſt; food muſt appeaſe him.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Cold meat will doe it, wil't not?

sp.speaker: Rim.
sp.l: Any thing—
That may imploy the teeth.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Goe James provide;
You are not merry yet.

sp.speaker: Catch.
sp.l: To ſatisfie you
In that point, we will ſing a Song of his.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Let's ha't; I love theſe Ballads hugeouſly.

sp.speaker: 1. Catch.
sp.l: THen our Muſick is in prime,
When our teeth keep triple time;
Hungry Notes are fit for Knels:
May lankenes be
No Queſt to me.
The Bagpipe ſounds, when that it ſwels.
Chor. May lankenes, &c.

sp.speaker: 2. Bagſh.
sp.l: A Mooting Night brings wholſome ſmiles,
When John an Okes, and John a Stiles,
Doe greaze the Lawyers Satin.
A Reading-Day
Frights French away,
The Benchers dare ſpeak Latin.
Chor. A Reading, &c.

sp.speaker: 3. Rim.
sp.l: He that's full doth Verſe compoſe;
Hunger deales in ſullen Proſe:
Take notice and diſcard her.
The empty Spit
Ne'r cheriſh'd Wit.
Minerva loves the Larder.
Chor. The empty Spit, &c.

sp.speaker: 4. Chr.
sp.l: Firſt to break Faſt, then to dine,
Is to conquer Bellarmine:
Diſtinctions then are budding.
Old Sutcliffs Wit
Did never hit,
But after his Bag-pudding.
Chor. Old Sutcliffs Wit, &c.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Moſt admirable; a good eating Song.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.l: Let us walk in, and practice it; my Bowels
Yern till I am in charity with all.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: A Chriſtian reſolution good Sr Chriſtopher.

div.head: ACT. III. SCEN. VI.
div.stage: Meanwell with a letter in his hand, Hearſay, Slicer.

sp.speaker: Mea.
sp.l: SWeet Sir I am moſt paſſionately yours,
To ſerve you all the waies I can. Priſcilla.
Very well Penn'd of a young Chambermaid,
I do conceive your meaning ſweet Priſcilla:
You ſee I have the happy fortune on't;
A night for nothing, and intreated too.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: Thou doſt not know how I do love thee; let me
Make uſe of this, thou'lt have the like occaſion.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: Thou art the fawningſt fellow Slicer—Meanwel Heark here.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: For Gods ſake be contented Sirs;
I'm fleſh and bloud as well as you. Lieutenant,
Think on your Suburb Beauties; ſweet Intelligencer,
I will by no means bar you of your Lady.
Your ſin I aſſure you will be honourable.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: Pox o'your liquorous lips; if that ſhe don't
After this ſealing forty weeks deliver
Something unto thee as thy act and deed,
Say I can't Propheſie.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: If I don't ſerve him
A trick he thinks not of—

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: Did'ſt mark how he
Did apply himſelf to the Knight all dinner?
I am afraid he plaies the cunning Factor,
And in anothers name woes for himſelf.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Let it go on; let it work ſomething farther
'Tis almoſt ripe enough to cruſh; he hath not
Crept high enough as yet to be ſenſible
Of any fall.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: Now is the time or never.
This night you know he and his Doxie meet;
Let me alone to give them their goodmorrow.
If that we carry things but one week longer
Without diſcovery, farewell London then;
The world's our own. He ne'r deſerves to thrive
That doth not venture for it. Wealth's then ſweet
When bought with hazzard. Fate this Law hath ſet;
The foole inherits, but the wiſe muſt get.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: MY Name's not Tribulation,
Nor holy Ananias:
I was baptiz'd in faſhion,
Our Vicar did hold Bias.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: What, how now Mr Credulous? ſo merry?

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: Come let's be mad; by yea and nay my Son
Shall have the Turkiſh Monarchy; he ſhall
Have it directly: the twelve Companies
Shall be his Kickſhaws.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Baſhaws Sir you mean.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: Well Sir, what if I do? Andrew the great Turk!
I would I were a pepper corn if that
It ſounds not well: do'ſt not?

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: Yes, very well.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: I'l make it elle: Great Andrew Mahomet,
Imperious Andrew Mahomet Credulous,
Tell me which name ſounds beſt.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: That's as you ſpeak 'em.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: Oatemeleman Andrew, Andrew Oatmeleman.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Ottoman Sir you meane.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: Yes Ottoman.
Then Mrs Jane, Sir Thomas Bitefiggs Daughter,
That may be the ſhe Great Turk, if ſhe pleaſe me.

sp.speaker: Sli.
sp.l: The Sign o'th' half Moon that hangs at your door,
Is not for nought.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: That's the Turks Armes they ſay;
The Empire's deſtin'd to our houſe directly.
Hang Shop-books, give's ſome Wine, hay for a noiſe
Of Fidlers now.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: The Great Turk loves no Muſick.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: Doe's he not ſo? nor I. I'l light Tobacco
With my Sum-totals; my Debt-books ſhall ſole
Pyes at young Andrew's Wedding: cry you mercy;
I would ſay Gentlemen the Great Turks Wedding.
My Deeds ſhall be ſlic'd out in Taylors Meaſures;
They all imploy'd in making Mrs Mahomet
New Gowns againſt the time; hang durty wealth.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.l: What ſhould the Great Turks father do wth wealth?

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: 'Snigs I would fain now heare
Some fighting News.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: There's one will furniſh you I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Pox!—Plague!—Hell!—Death!—
Damn'd luck!—this 'tis!—
The Devill take all Fortunes: never man
Came off ſo▪ quite and clean defunct by Heaven—
Not a peece left.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: What all your Ord'nance loſt?

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: But one to bear, and loſe it! all the world
Was ſure againſt me.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: 'Snigs how many fell?

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: He threw twice twelve.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: By'r Lady a ſhrewd many.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: The Devill ſure was in his hand I think.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: Nay, if the Devill was againſt you, then—

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: But one for to be hit in all the time—
And that too ſafe enough to any ones thinking;
'T ſtood on eleven.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: 'Slid a mighty ſlaughter;
But did he ſtand upon elev'n at once?

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: The Plague take all impertinencies, peace.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: Theſe Souldiers are ſo cholerick there is
No dealing with 'em; then they've loſt the day.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: 'Twas ten to one by Heaven all the while.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: And yet all kill'd at laſt? hard fortune faith.
What news from Bruxels? or the Hague? d' y' heare
Ought of the Turks deſigns?

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: I'l make thee news
For the Coranti Dotard.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: Ay, the Coranti,
What doth that ſay?

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: O hell! thou fooliſh thing
Keep in that tongue of thine, or—

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: Good now peace,
He's very furious when he's mov'd.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: This 'twas.
You muſt be ventring without your Fancy-man.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: What Officer's that Fancy-man, Lieutenant?
Some great Commander ſure.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Pox! let it go;
I'l win't again: 'twas but the Reliques of
An idle hundred.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: 'Snigs and well remember'd.
You did receive the hundred that I ſent you
To th' Race this morning by your man, my Bayliffe?

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Take him away, his wine ſpeaks in him now.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: Godſnigs the Farme is mine, and muſt be ſo.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: Debate theſe things another time, good friends.
Come, come, have Patience. Od's my life away.
There's Mr Haveatall is mad; hee'l ſpit you,
If he but know you are a Uſurer.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: A plot, a plot to take away my life and Farm.

sp.speaker: Have.
sp.l: Fight as I live with any one. Lieutenant
Do not come neer me now, nor yet thou Caſter;
It works, 'fore Mars it works; I'l take my walk,
And if I do find any one by Iove—

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: What's he fox'd too? ſome drunken Planet raigns
And works upon the world; Provide my fancie
God Noble Patron: I'l win ſoberly,
I itch till I have beggard all the City.

sp.speaker: Hea.
sp.l: Till that you have undone your ſelf you mean. En.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Ey ſave you both: for derne love ſayen ſoothly Mo.
Where is thylk amebly, Francklin, cleped Meanwel?

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Hee's gone abroad.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Lere me whylk way he wended.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: He is gon o'r the fields.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: To the Knights houſe.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Why laugh you every dele? ſo mote I gone,
This goeth not aright; I dread ſome Covin.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: Now will he meet with Haveatall; there'll be
A Combate worthy Chronicle. Let's go
And ſee how this grave motion will beſtir him.

div.head: ACT IV. SCEN. II.
div.stage: Haveatall, after a while Moth, Slicer and Hearſay watching.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: VVHat, no man yet march by? who e'r comes next
I'l give him onerap more for making me
Stay here ſo long.
So ſo here h'is; how ſhall
I do to know where he be a Gentleman,
Or Yeoman or Serving-man? I think
I'd beſt ſuppoſe him all, and beat him through
Every degree, and ſo I ſhall not wrong him.
What? who goes there?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: Waes heal thou gentle Knight.

sp.speaker: Hav.
sp.l: Waes heal thou gentle Knight? ſpeak what art thou?
Speak quickly doe: Villain know'ſt thou not me?

sp.speaker: Moth
sp.l: Now by my troath I know not your Name;
Whider I ſhall call you my Lord Dan John,
Or Dan Thomas, or Dan Robert, or Dan Albon:
I vow to God thou haſt a full faire chine;
Upon my faith art ſome Officer.

sp.speaker: Hav.
sp.l: Have you the pox Sir? ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Hav.
sp.l: No? nor yet
An ach in your Bones!

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Hav.
sp.l: No? why then you are
No Gentleman; Lieutenant Slicer ſays ſo.
This cudgell then ſerves turn.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: You will not foyn?

sp.speaker: Hav.
sp.l: I will not foyn, but I will beat you Sir.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: Why intermete of what thou haſt to done;
So leteth me alone, 't ſhall be thy beſt.

sp.speaker: Hav.
sp.l: I fancy'd you a beating; you muſt have it.
You ſhall not ſay but I will ſhew you favour.
Chooſe where you will be hacked with my ſword,
Or bruis'd by my Batton.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: Dre not thy true,
And paynant Morglay out of Shete. Lo thus
Eftſoons Sir Knight, I greet thee lowting low.

sp.speaker: Hav.
sp.l: Done lower yet.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: Rueth on my gray haires.

sp.speaker: Hav.
sp.l: Yet lower: ſo, then thus I do beſtride thee.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: Tubal the ſonne of Lamech did yfind
Muſick by knocking Hammers upon Anviles;
Let go thine blows, thylke Art is no compleat.

sp.speaker: Hav.
sp.l: Doſt thou make me a Smith thou Rogue? a Tubal?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.l: Harrow alas! flet England, flet England:
Dead is Edmond.

sp.speaker: Hav.
sp.l: Take that for hiſtory.
O brave Lieutenant now thy dinner works.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: I nis not Edmond Ironſide God wot.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: More provocation yet? I'l ſeal thy lips.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: A twenty Devil way! So did the Saxon
Upon thylke plain of Sarum, done to death
By treachery, the Lords of merry Englond
Nem eſur Saxes.

sp.speaker: Have.
sp.l: Villain doſt abuſe me
In unbaptized language? do not anſwer;
If that thou doſt, by Iove I'l ſtrangle thee.
Do you make mouths you Raskall thus at me?
You're at dumb Service now: why, this is more
Unſufferable than your old patch'd gibberiſh;
This ſilence is abuſe. I'l ſend thee to
The Place of it, where thou ſhalt meet with Oſwald,
Vortigern, Harold, Hengiſt, Horſey, Knute,
Alared, Edgar, and Cunobeline.
Thus, thus I ſheath my Sword.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: Redoubled Knight
Enough, 'tis thy foe doth vanquiſh'd lie
Now at thy mercy, mercy notwithſtand,
For he is one the trueſt Knight alive,
Though conquer'd now he lie on lowly ground.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: Thou ow'ſt thy life to my Lieutenant, Caitife.
Breath and be thankfull.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: I reche not thine yeft;
Maugre thine head, algate I ſuffer none,
I am-thine lefe, thine deere, mine Potluck Jone.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: FAireſt of things—tralucent creature—Hang me
If I do know what's next.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.l: This meant to mee?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Faireſt of things— tralucent creature— rather
Obſcured Deity—'Tis gone again.
Lady will you eat a peece of Gingerbread?

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.l: You might have better manners than to ſcoff
One of my breeding.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Heark; indad I love you.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.l: Alas!

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I vow I burn in love, as doth
A penny Faggot.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.l: Hey ho!

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: And I ſhall
Blaze out Sir reverence if ye do not quench me.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.l: Indeed now?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Though I ſay't that ſhould not ſay't,
I am affected towards you ſtrangely.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.l: Now who'd have thought it?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: There's a thing each night
Comes to my Bedshead and cries Matrimony,
Matrimony Andrew.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.l: God forbid.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: It is
Some Spirit that would joyn us.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Goodly, goodly.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Then do I ſhake all over.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.l: Doth it ſo?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Then ſhake again.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.l: I pray you now.

sp.speaker: • nd.
sp.l: Then cry
〈◊〉 of things—tralucent creature—rather
Obſcured Deity, ſweet Mrs Jane,
I come I come.

sp.speaker: Priſc.
sp.l: Sweet Sir you are deceiv'd:
I'm but her woeman; here ſhe comes her ſelf.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Now as my Father ſaith, I would I were
A Cucumber if I know what to doe.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: Why how now Priſ? who's that that uſeth you
So lovingly?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Faireſt of things—'tis one
Tralucent Creature—'tis—Ay that it is
One—

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.l: That would willingly run out of doores,
If that he had but Law enough.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: I ſay—

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: Nay ben't afraid: here's none ſhall doe you harm.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: 'Tis one that brought his Pigs to the wrong market.
You keep your woman here ſo fine, that I
Had like t' have made a proper buſineſſe on't
Before I was aware. If any thing
Doe prove amiſſe, indeed-law you ſhall be
The Father on't. But know tralucent Creature
I am come off entire, and now am yours
Whole, Andrew Creaulous, your ſervants ſervant.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: Methinks you contradict your ſelf: how can you
Be wholly mine, and yet my ſervants ſervant?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: I doe but complement in that (I ſee
Downright's the beſt way here) if thou canſt love
I can love too. Law thee there now. I'm rich.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: I uſe not to look after riches; 'tis
The perſon that I aime at.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: That is me;
I'm proper, handſome faire, clean-limb'd: I'm rich.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: I muſt have one that can direct and guide me;
A Guardian rather than a Husband; for
I'm fooliſh yet.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Now ſee the luck on't Lady
So am I too Ifaith.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: And who e'r hath me
Will find me to be one of thoſe things which
His care muſt firſt reform.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Do not doubt that;
I have a head for Reformation:
This noddle here ſhall do it. I am rich.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: Riches create no love; I fear you mean
To take me for formality only,
As ſome ſtaid peece of houſholdſtuff perhaps
Fit to be ſeen 'mong other ornaments:
Or at the beſt I ſhall be counted but
A name of dignity; not entertain'd
For love but State; one of your train, a thing
Took to wipe off ſuſpicion from ſome fairer
To whom you have vow'd Homage.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Do not think
I've any Plots or Projects in my Head,
I will do any thing for thee that thou
Canſt name or think on.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.l: Pray you try him Miſtris,
By my Virginity I think hee'l flinch.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: By my Virginity (which is as good
As yours I'm ſure) by my Virginity
If that we men have any ſuch thing (as
We men haue ſuch a thing) I do beleeve
I will not flinch. Alas! you don't know Andrew.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: Can you obtain but ſo much reſpite from
Your other Soverains ſervice, as to keep
Your Eye from gazing on her for a while?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: If I do look on any woman, nay,
If I do caſt a ſheeps eye upon any
But your ſweet ſelf, may I loſe one of mine:
Marry I'l keep the other howſoe'r.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: I know not how I may beleeve you; you'l
Swear you ne'r caſt a glance on any, when
Your eye hath baited at each face you met.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Blind me good now: being you miſtruſt, I will
Be blinded with this handkercheife; you ſhall
See that I love you now. So, let me have
But any reaſonable thing to lead me home,
I do not care though 't be a Dog, ſo that
He knows the way, or hath the wit t' enquire it.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.l: That care Sir ſhall be mine.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I doubt not, but
I ſhall be in the Chronicle for this,
Or in a Balled elſe. This handkercheif
Shall be hung up i'th' Pariſh Church inſteed
Of a great ſilken flag to fan my grave:
With my Arms in't, pourtray'd in good blew thread
With this word underneath: This, this was he
That ſhut his eyes becauſe he would not ſee.
Hold who comes there?

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: One Sir to lead you home.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Who? Tutor Meanwell?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Yes I do commit you
Unto your truſty friend, If you perform
This vow we may—

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I'l ſay your ſentence out,
Be man and wife.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: If you'l do ſomething elſe
That I'l propoſe.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Pray make your own conditions.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: You'l promiſe me you'l not be jealous of me?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Do what you will I'l truſt you.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: never hire
Any to tempt me?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: By this light (I would ſay
By this darkneſſe) I never will.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Nor mark
On whom I laugh?—

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Nor ſuſpect My ſmiles,
My nods, my winks?—

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: No, no.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Nor yet keep count
From any Gallants viſit?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I'l ne'r reckon;
You ſhall do what you will.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: You'l never ſet
Great Cheſts and Formes againſt my Chamber Door,
Nor pin my ſmock unto your ſhirt a nights,
For fear I ſhould ſlip from you ere you wake?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: As I do hope for Day I will not.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Give me
Some ſmall pledge from you to aſſure your love;
If that you yet prove falſe, I may have ſomething
To witneſſe your inconſtancy. I'l take
This little Ruby: this ſmall bluſhing ſtone
From your fair finger.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Take it Sweet: there is
A Diamond in my Bandſtring, if you have
A mind to that I pray make uſe of't too.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: In troth a ſtone of luſtre, I aſſure you
It darts a pretty light, a veget ſpark;
It ſeems an Eye upon your Breaſt.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Nay take it,
For loves ſake take it then; leave nothing that
Looks like an Eye about me.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: My good Andrew,
'Cauſe of thy reſolution, I'l perform
This office for thee. Take my word for't, this
Shall ne'r betray thee.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Farewell honeſt Jany,
I cannot ſee to thank thee my ſweet Jany.
Tutor, your hand good Tutor, lead me wiſely.

sp.speaker: Mea.
sp.l: Take comfort man; I have good news for thee:
Thine eyes ſhall be thine own before next morning.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: HEe's a good friend of mine, and I preſume
Upon your ſecreſie.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: O Sir—the Deed
By which it came was not more cloſe. D'y'think
I would undo me ſelf by twitting? 'twere
To bring the Gallants all about mine Ears,
And make me mine own Patient. I'm faithfull,
And ſecret, though a Barber.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Nay, but hear me;
Hee's very modeſt: 'twas his firſt attempt
Procur'd him this infirmity; he will
Be baſhfull I am ſure, and won't be known
Of any ſuch thing at the firſt; you muſt
Be ſure to put him to't.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Let me alone,
He knows not yet the world I do perceive.
It is as common now with Gentlemen,
As 'tis to follow faſhion; only here
Lyeth the difference, that they keep in this
A little longer. I ſhall have ſo much
Upon your word Sir?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: If you do perform
The cure by that time (twenty peeces Sir.)
You are content?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: It ſhall be done
According to your own preſcription.
Sit down I pray you Sir, this Gentleman
Is a good friend of yours.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Indeed he is
A very honeſt man as any one
Can wiſh to deal with verily.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Beleeve't
He loves you very well.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I am moſt ready
To do him any ſervice truly; pray you
Good Brother don't delay me, I'm in haſte.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Indeed, and truly, verily good Brother;
How could theſe milk-ſop words e'r get him company
That could procure the Pox? where do you feel
You grief moſt trouble you?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I'm very well.
What mean you Brother?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Nay, be not ſo modeſt;
'Tis no ſuch hainous fault, as that you ſhould
Seek thus to hide it: meer ill fortune only—

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Surely you do forget your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Come, come,
He told me you'ld be ſhamefac'd; you muſt be
Wary hereafter.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: (I do perceive
He is a little mad indeed; the Gentleman
Told me ſo much juſt as I came along)
Yes, yes, I'l be wary, I'l take heed,
Come pray y' diſpatch me.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: So, I like you now.
It is the cuſtome of moſt Gentlemen
Not to confeſſe untill they feel their bones
Begin t' admoniſh 'em.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You are i'th' right:
Good friend make haſte; I've very urgent buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Not raſhly neither; Is your Griſtle ſound?
Me thinks 'tis very firm as yet to th' touch.
You fear no danger there as yet Sir, do you?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: No, I'l aſſure you. (He muſt have his humour;
I ſee he is not to be croſs'd.)

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: When did you
Feel the firſt grudging on't? 'tis not broke out
In any place?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: No, no: I pray y' diſpatch me.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Theſe things deſire deliberation;
Care is requir'd.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Good Brother go t'your Cheſt.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: How can I know what Med'cines to apply,
If that you tell me not where lies your grief?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Nay good now let me go.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I muſt not Sir,
Nor will not truly: truſt me you will wiſh
You had confeſs'd and ſuffer'd me in time,
When you ſhall come to dry burnt Racks of Mutton,
The Syren, and the Tub.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: So now enough;
Pray fetch me what you promis'd.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Are you wild,
Or mad? I do proteſt I ne'r did meet
A Gentleman of ſuch perverſneſſe yet.
I find you juſt as I was told you ſhould.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I loſe the taking, by my ſwear, of taking
As much, whiles that I am receiving this.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I will not hinder you, if that you do
Prefer your gain before your health.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Well then
I pray you tell it out; we Tradeſmen are not
Maſters of our own time.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: What would you have?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: What would I have? as if you did not know;
Come come leave jeſting now at laſt good Brother.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: I am in earneſt Sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Why, I would have
My money Sir, the twenty peeces that
The Gentleman did give you order now
To pay me for the Velvet, that he bought
This morning of me.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: O! the Gentleman—

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You ſhould not make a laughing ſtock good Brother
Of one that wrongs you not; I do profeſſe
I won't be fubb'd enſure your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: The Gentleman!
Oh! oh! the Gentleman! is this the cure
I ſhould perform? truly I dare not venture
Upon ſuch de ſperate Maladies.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You are
But merrily diſpos'd?

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: Indeed they are
Too high for my ſmall Quality; verily
Perhaps good Brother you might periſh under
Mine hands truly; I do profeſs I am not
Any of your bold Mountebanks in this.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You're ſtill diſpos'd—

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: To laugh at you good Brother.
Gull'd by my ſwear, by my ſwear gull'd; he told me
You had a ſmall infirmity upon you,
A griefe of youth, or two; and that I ſhould
Have twenty peeces for the cure. He ask'd you
If that you were content, you anſwered yes.
I was in hope I'd gain'd a Patient more;
Your beſt way is to make haſte after him.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Now could I beat my ſelf for a wiſe fool
That I was, thus to truſt him.

sp.speaker: Chi.
sp.l: B'w'y' Brother.
'Fore God a good one. O! the Gentleman.

div.head: ACT. IV. SCEN. V.
div.stage: Rimewell, Bagſhot, Catchmey, Sir Chriſtopher; A Song at a window; congratulating (as they think) Mr Meanwels Marriage.

lg.l: Whiles early light ſprings from the skies,
A fairer from your Bride doth riſe;
A brighter Day doth thence appear,
And make a ſecond morning there:
Her bluſh doth ſhed
All o'r the bed,
Clean ſhamefac'd beames
That ſpread in ſtreames,
And purple round the modeſt aire.
I will not tell what ſhreeks, and cries,
What Angry Diſhes, and what ties,
What pretty oaths then newly born
The liſtning Taper heard there ſworn:
Whiles froward ſhe
Moſt peeviſhly
Did yielding fight
To keep o'r night
What ſhee'd have profer'd you ere morn.
Faire, we know, maids do refuſe
To grant what they do come to loſe.
Intend a Conqueſt you that wed;
They would be chaſtly raviſhed.
Not any kiſſe
From Mrs Pris,
If that you do
Perſwade and woe.
Know pleaſure's by extorting fed.
O may her arms wax black and blew
Only by hard encircling you:
May ſhe round about you twine
Like the eaſie twiſting Vine;
And whiles you ſip
From her full lip
Pleaſures as new
As morning Dew,
Let thoſe ſoft Tyes your hearts combine.

sp.speaker: Sing.
sp.l: God give you joy Mr Meanwell. God give your Worſhip good morrow.

sp.speaker: Rim.
sp.l: Come let's be going.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Hold, a blow I'l have,
One jerk at th' times, wrap'd in a benediction
O'th' Spouſes teeming, and I'l go with you.

div.head: A Song.
div.l: NOw thou our future Brother,
That ſhalt make this Spouſe a Mother,
Spring up, and Dod's bleſſing on't.
Shew thy little ſorrell Pate
And prove regenerate
Before thou be brought to the Font.
May the Pariſh Surplice be
Cut in peeces quite for thee,
To wrap thy ſoft body about;
So 'twill better ſervice do
Reformed thus into
The ſtate of an Orthodox Clout.
When thou ſhalt leave the Cradle,
And ſhalt begin to waddle,
And trudge in thy little Apron;
Mayſt thou conceive a grace
Of half an hours ſpace,
And rejoice in thy Friday Capon.
For an errour that's the Flocks
Name Mr Paul, but urge St Knoxe;
And at every reform'd Dinner,
Let cheeſe come in, and preaching,
And by that third Courſe teaching,
Confirm an unſatisfi'd Sinner.
Thence grow up to hate a Ring,
And defie an offering:
And learn to ſing what others ſay.
Let Chriſt-tide be thy faſt,
And lent thy good repaſt:
And regard not an Holy day.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Lay hold on them; lay hold on them I ſay:
I'l hamper them.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: Hell take your headlong zeale;
You muſt be jerking at the times forſooth.
I am afraid the times will ſcape, and we
The men of them ſhall ſuffer now the ſcourge.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Let none eſcape.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.l: 'Twas godlineſs verily:
It was a Hymn I warbled.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Thou doſt lye,
It was no Hymn, it was a Song. Is this
Your filthy Rendevow? you ſhall be taught
Another tune.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: I do beſeech you ſhew
Mercifull cruelty, and as 'twere a kind
Of pittifull hard heartedneſſe. I'm ſtrong.

div.stage: They bring in Andrew, and Priſcilla.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I'm glad you told me ſo, I will provide
Your Ward accordingly. Drag 'em out both.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Let me but ſend to th' Ordinary.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: You ſhall not,
The Ord'nary hath ſent to you: No Baile,
I will take none. I'l ſuffer no ſuch ſneaks
As you, t'offend this way. It doth belong
T'your Betters Sir.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Here's a ſufficient Man
I do aſſure you, take my word for that.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: This ſtaff was made to knock down ſin. I'l look
There ſhall be no Advowtry in my Ward
But what is honeſt. I'l ſee Juſtice done
As long as I'm in office. Come along.

div.head: ACT. V. SCENE I.
div.stage: Sir Thomas Bitefig as ſick, Iane.

sp.speaker: Sr Tho.
sp.l: NOw that I have made ev'n Girl, with Heav'n.
Though I am paſt the worſt, and I perceive
My dinner only griev'd me, yet 'cauſe Life's
Frail, and uncertain, let me counſell thee,
'Tis good to be before hand ſtill. Firſt then
I charge thee lend no money; next ſerve God;
If ever thou haſt Children teach 'em thrift;
They'l learn Religion faſt enough themſelves.
Nay, do not weep but hearken. When Heav'n ſhall
Pleaſe to call in this Weary Soul of mine,
Ben't idle in expence about my Burial;
Buy me a ſhroud, any old ſheet will ſerve
To cloath corruption; I can rot without
Fine linnen; 'tis but to enrich the Grave,
And adorn ſtench, no reverence to the dead,
To make 'em crumble more luxuriouſly.
One Torch will be ſufficient to direct
The footſteps of my Bearers. If there be
Any ſo kind as to accompanie
My body to the Earth, let them not want
For entertainment, prethee ſee they have
A ſprig of Roſemary dip'd in common water,
To ſmell to as they walk along the ſtreets.
Eatings and drinkings are no obſequies.
Raiſe no oppreſſing Pile to load my Aſhes;
But if thou'l needs b' at charges of a Tomb,
Five or ſix foot of common ſtone engrav'd
With a good hopefull word, or elſe a couple
Of capital letters filled up with pitch,
Such as I ſet upon my Sheep, will ſerve;
State is not meet for thoſe that dwell in duſt.
Mourn as thou pleaſeſt for me, plainneſs ſhews
True grief: I give thee leave to do it for
Two or three years, if that thou ſhalt think fit.
'Twill ſave expence in cloaths. And ſo now be
My bleſſing on thee, and my means hereafter.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: I hope Heav'n will not deal ſo rigidly
With me, as to preſerve me to th' unmelcome
Performance of theſe ſad injunctions.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: GOod health unto you Sir.

sp.speaker: Sr Tho.
sp.l: I have the more
By reaſon of the care you took in ſending
A Confeſſor unto me.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: I? a Confeſſor?
Sure there is ſome deſign, ſome trick or other
Put on you by thoſe men, who never ſleep
Unleſs they've cheated on that Day.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.l: I hope
You do mean your Partners my good friends?

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: They ne'r deſerve the name of friends, they do
Covet, not love. If any came from them,
It was ſome Vulture in a holy habit,
Who did intend your Carkaſſe, nor your ſafety;
Indeed I know not of't, I've all this while
Appear'd another to you than I am.
Perhaps you know me now. I'm he whom you
Pleas'd to forbid your houſe, whom Mr Credulous
Takes leave to ſtile loſt man, and Vagabond.

sp.speaker: Sr Tho.
sp.l: That I forbad you Sir my houſe was only
In care to my Daughter, not in hate to you.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: That I frequented it without your leave,
Was both in love to you, and to your Daughter;
That I have all this while liv'd thus diſguis'd,
Was only to avert the ſnare from you,
Not to intrap you; that you might not be
Blinded by thoſe, who like to venemous Beaſts,
Have only ſight to poyſon; that you might not
Ruine your Daughter in a complement.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.l: This may b' your plot, and this diſcoverie
Feign'd only to ſecure your own deſigns:
For 't cannot ſink into me that they durſt
Make mirth of my repentance, and abuſe
My laſt devotion with a Scene of Laughter.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: They dare beyond your thought. When parted this
Your Confeſſor?

sp.speaker: Sr Tho.
sp.l: You could not chuſe but meet him,
He is ſcarce yet at home.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: If that you dare
But venture with me home, I'l almoſt promiſe
I'l make it plain they've put a trick upon you.

sp.speaker: Sr Tho.
sp.l: Though every ſtep were ſo much toward my grave
I'd tread them o'r with comfort that I might
Diſcover this religious villany.

div.head: ACT V. SCEN. III.
div.stage: Hearſay, Slicer, and Shape in his Confeſſors habit.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: COme my good Vulture ſpeak what prey? what mirth?

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: What income my dear holineſs? what ſport?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Give me the Chair; imagine me the Knight
(When I ſit down,) and (when I ſtand) the Confeſſor.
sp.stage: As he is thus acting, Meanwell and Sir Thomas diſcover themſelves above.
sp.l: Thus I come in peace to thy ſoul good Son,
(Tis you muſt give it Father; I am ill,
I'm very ill; ſit only now for Heav'n.
My Soul would fain be flying, were't not for
A Sin or two that clogs her.) But for a ſin
Or two that clogs her? take heed, don't ſo neer
Your laſt deliverance play the Sophiſter
With Heav'n. A ſin or two? why, I've heard ſay
You're wont to skrew your wretched Tenants up
To th' utmoſt farthing, and then ſtand upon
The third Rent Capon. Then he anſwers me
In the ſmall dolfull tune of a Country wench
Examin'd by th' Officiall, for the miſchance
Of a great belly caught at a Whitſonale;
(I could not help it.) Then it is your coſtome
When you invite, to think your meat laid out,
You write your Beef disburs'd, are wont to call
For the return of 't juſt, as for a debt;
(True.) That two Chimneys ne'r yet ſmok'd at once
In all your Buildings; (All moſt true.) That you
Are wont to keep an untouch'd Capon, till
Corruption makes it able to walk out
And viſit the Barn Door again: I could
Say much more, but I'd rather have you
Come ſo much nearer pardon, as t'accuſe
Your ſelf by your own mouth.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: How grave the Rogue was?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: (I'l do 't as ſtrictly as mine Enemy.)

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.l: I cannot hold; I'l break in as I am,
And take my vengeance whiles my furie's hot.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: Repreſs it Sir a while; h' hath but begun.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Then thus he dralls it out. (I do confeſs
I've been addicted to frugality.)
Son do not mince; pray call it Covetouſneſs.
(Imprimis It hath ever been my cuſtome
To ride beyond an Inn to ſave my horſe meat.
Item, When once I had done ſo, and found
No entertainment, I beguild the children
Of their parch'd peaſe, my Man being left to that
We make the embleme of mortality:)
What? graſs you mean? (or ſweet Hay which you pleaſe.)

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Me thinks this 's truly coming to a Reckoning,
He doth account for's ſins with Item ſo.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: (Item I've often bought a Cheapſide Cuſtard,
And ſo refreſh'd my ſoul under my Cloak,
As I did walk the ſtreets.) Cloaking of ſins,
Although they be but eating ſins, I do
Pronounce moſt dangerous. (I find this ſo,
I'd almoſt loſt mine Eyes by't being juſtled.)

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: O thou rich ſoul of Roguery.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: (Moreover
I once ſung Pſalmes with Servants where I lodg'd,
And took part with 'em in their lovely Reliques;
Truly my ſoul did luſt, they were Temptations.)
What ſing that you might eat? It is the ſin
O'th'Brethren Son; but that their Reliques are
Whole widows houſes.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: O thou preaching Devill!

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: (Item I enter'd into a Chandlers ſhop,
And eat my bread in ſecret, whiles my man
Fed on the wholſome ſteem of Candle ſewet.
Item, which grieves me moſt, I did make bold
With the Black Puddings of my needy Taylor;
Satan was ſtrong, they did provoke me much.)

sp.speaker: Sr Tho.
sp.l: Wretch that I was to truſt my boſome to
One ſo exactly bad, that if the book
Of all mens lives lay open to his view
Would meet no ſin unpractis'd by himſelf.
I will ruſh in.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: Good Sir keep cloſe a while,

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I ſee no tears, no penetentiall tears.
(Alas! I cannot weep, mine Eyes are Pumice.
But Alms I hope may yet redeem.) Alms giv'n
In a large manner Son. (Won't fifty pounds
Wipe off my ſcore?) If doubled't may do ſomething.
(Can I be ſav'd no cheaper? take this then
And pray for me.) With that I thus diſmiſs'd him.
Bleſt Son, for now I dare pronounce thee bleſt,
Being thou'ſt powr'd thus out thy ſoul— The wolf!
The wolf! 'sfoot peace, we're in the nooſe:
We are betrai'd, yon's Meanwell and the Knight—
Truly he is as good a man as any
I ever yet confeſs'd—don't look that way—
A very honeſt charitable man,
Full of ſincerity, and true devotion.

sp.speaker: Sr Tho.
sp.l: Patience it ſelf would now turn furious,
Let's for ſome Officers.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Diſcover'd all!
Religion is unluckie to me.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Man!
Perfidious man! there is no truſt in thee!

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: I never lik'd this Meanwell; I did alwaies
See treachery writ in's forehead: I well hop'd
H'ad been in Priſon with his wench.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: leave railing.
Along with me. There is left one way more;
The Cat may yet perhaps light on all foure.

div.head: ACT. V. SCEN. IV.
div.stage: Sir Thomas Bitefig, Meanwell, Conſtable, Watchmen.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.l: VVHat gone? upon my life they did miſtruſt.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: They are ſo beaten that they ſmell an Officer,
As Crows do Powder.

sp.speaker: Sr Tho.
sp.l: Watchman call you forth
The Miſtris of the houſe, Imprimis, for
They have their lurking hole near hand moſt certain.

div.stage: Enter Moth, and Potluck as Man and Wife.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Denuncio vobis gaudium magnum,
Robertus de Tinea electus eſt in ſedem Hoſpitalem,
Et aſſumit ſibi nomen Galfridi.
Joy comes to our houſe. I Robert Moth am
Cheſen into thylk Hoſpitall ſeat▪
Thylk Baſon of Jone Potluck, Vintners Widow▪
And do tranſmue my name to Giffery.
New foyſons byn ygraced with new Titles.
Come buſs.

sp.speaker: Pot.
sp.l: Fie! Mr Giffery I ſwear
You make m' aſham'd 'fore all this Company.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.l: Sir, if you be the Maſter of this houſe,
You've harbor'd here a company of cheating Villains,
Which we are come to apprehend.

sp.speaker: Pot.
sp.l: Pray y' look,
Search every Corner, here's no cheats. I'm ſure
The houſe was clear before your Worſhip entred.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Make faſt the Doors for fear they do eſcape.
Let's in and ferret out theſe cheating Rakehels.

div.stage: As the Watchmen go in and out about the Rooms Hearſay, Slicer, and Shape mingle themſelves with 'em, being accounted Watchmen, and ſo paſs without diſcovery.

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.l: 'Tis very certain they are not in the houſe.

sp.speaker: Sr Tho.
sp.l: They had no time to get away.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Why then,
It may be being they are ſuch cunning Fellows,
They have the trick of going inviſible.

sp.speaker: 2 Watch.
sp.l: There's no place left unſearch'd but Pots and Mouſeholes.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: They're either gone or in the Houſe that's certain.

sp.speaker: 2 Watchm.
sp.l: That cannot be; the Doors were ſhut I'm ſure,
And ſo they could not get out; the Rooms then are
All ſearch'd, and ſo they cannot be within.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: I'l lay my neck to a farthing, then they're vaniſh'd.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Sunk like the Queen, they'l riſe at Queenhive ſure.

div.stage: Enter Conſtable, and other Watchmen, and Shape among 'em, bringing in Credulous, and Caſter.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Moſt certain theſe are two of them: for this▪
Old Knave, I'l take my Oath that he is one.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Confeſs, confeſs, where are your other Comrads?

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: I am as honeſt as the skin that is
Between thy Brows?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: What skin between my Brows?
What skin thou knave? I am a Chriſtian;
And what is more, a Conſtable; what skin?

sp.speaker: Sr Tho.
sp.l: You are miſtaken friends.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I cry you mercy.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: The Conſtable may call you any thing
In the Kings name upon ſuſpicion.

sp.speaker: Sr Tho.
sp.l: We're cheated friends; theſe men o'th' Ordnary
Have gull'd us all this while, and now are gone.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: I am undon. Ne'r let me live if that
I did not think th' would gull me, I perceive
Fanſie doth much; ſee how 'tis come to paſs.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: Where is my Son God bleſſe him? where is Andrew?
Pray God they have not taken him along;
He hath a perilous wit to be a cheat;
He'd quickly come to be his Majeſties Taker.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I took one Andrew Credulous this morning
In diſhoneſt Adultery with a Trull.
And if he be your Son he is in Priſon.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: Their villany o' my life. Now as I am
A Freeman and a Grocer, I had rather
Have found forty pounds; I pray go fetch him.

sp.speaker: Sr Tho.
sp.l: I'm ſorry that your Son takes theſe lewd courſes;
He is not fit to make a Husband of.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: Do not condemn before you hear. I'l warrant
Though he be guilty yet hee's innocent.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Hent him, for dern love Hent him; I done drad
His Viſage foul, yfrounct with glowing eyn.

sp.speaker: Have.
sp.l: I come t' excuſe my ruder uſage of you.
I was in drink when that I did it: 'twas
The Plot of thoſe baſe Knaves, I hear are gone,
To teach me valour by the ſtrength of Wine;
Naming that courage which was only fury.
It was not wilfully.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: I do not reche
One bean for all. This Buſs is a blive guerdon.
Hence Carliſhneſſe yferre. 'Tis a ſooth ſaw,
Had I but venged all mine herme,
Mine Cloak had not been furred half ſo werme.

div.stage: Enter Officers with Andrew, Priſcilla, and the four that were taken at the Window ſinging.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: Now Sir you ſhall hear all. Come Andrew tell me,
How camſt thou hither?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Truly Mr Meanwel
Told me that I ſhould meet with Mrs Jane,
And there I found her Chamber-maid.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: D'y' ſee?
Your Chamber-maid Sir Thomas; out you whore.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Take heed what you ſay Father, ſhee's my wife.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: I would thou'rt in thy grave, then 'twere the better
Fortune o'th' two.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.l: Indeed this reverend Man
Joyn'd us i'th' Priſon.

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: Marriage is a Bond,
So no place fitter to perform it in.

sp.speaker: Sr Tho.
sp.l: Send for my Daughter hither, wee'l know all.
What are you Sir?

sp.speaker: Chr.
sp.l: A workman in the Clergie.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Yes, this is one I took at th' Window ſinging,
With theſe three other vagrant Fellows here.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.l: I was in body there, but not in mind,
So that my ſin is but inchoately perfect,
And I though in a fault did not offend,
And that for three reaſons. Firſt, I did yield
Only a kind of unwilling conſent.
Secondly, I was drawn as 'twere by their
Impulſive gentleneſs. Mark Sir I'm ſtrong.
Thirdly, I deem'd it not a womans-ſhambles:
Fourthly and laſtly, that I ſung was only
An holy wiſh. Once more Beloved.

sp.speaker: Sr Tho.
sp.l: Peace!
Y'have ſaid enough already. How came you
To ſing beneath the Window?

sp.speaker: Rime.
sp.l: Mr Hearſay
Told us that Mr Meanwell was new married,
And thought it good that we ſhould gratifie him,
And ſhew our ſelves to him in a Feſtennine.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: That Raskall Meanwel was the cauſe of all,
I would I had him here.

sp.speaker: Sr Tho.
sp.l: Why? this is he,
Sr Robert Littleworth his Son, he hath
Diſclos'd their vilanies; he is no cheat.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: God ſave you Mr Credulous; you have
Forgotten me perhaps, I'm ſomewhat chang'd,
You ſee your loſt man's found; your Vagabond
Appears at laſt.

sp.speaker: Cre.
sp.l: Go, you are a gibing ſcab:
Leave off your flouting; you're a beardleſs Boy;
I am a Father of Children.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: And your Son
Will be ſo ſhortly, if he han't ill luck.
To vex you more, that hundred pounds you ſent
To Mr Caſter, Shape i'th' habit of
A Country fellow gull'd you of.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: That Raskall;
Thou ſhewſt thy wit t' abuſe an old man thus.
As God ſhall mend me I will hamper thee.
Thou'ſt been diſguis'd here all this while, thou haſt;
Would I were braid in mine own morter, if
I do not call th' in Queſtion the next Terme
For counterfeiting of the Kings Subjects.
Come away from him Sirrah, come along.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: There's a Trunk they've left behind; I have
Seiz'd it for you; ſo that you'l be no loſer.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.l: If you can find a way whereby I may
Reward this courteſie of yours, I ſhall
Confeſs my ſelf engaged doubly to you,
Both for the benefit and its requitall.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: The appearance of your Daughter here ſuggeſts
Something to ask, which yet my thoughts call boldneſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.l: Can ſhe ſuggeſt yet any good, that is
So expert grown in this fleſh Brokery?

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: O do not blot that Innocence with ſuſpicion,
Who never came ſo neere a blemiſh yet,
As to b' accus'd. To quit you of ſuch thoughts
I did receive a tempting letter from
That Strumpet that's gone out (as ſin is bold
To try even where no hope is) I made promiſe,
But to ſecure my ſelf, and withall ſound
Th' affections of young Credulous unto
Your vertuous Daughter, told him he ſhould meet her
Where I agreed to meet her Chambermaid.
The blame muſt all be mine.

sp.speaker: Sr Tho.
sp.l: 'Tis her deliverance.
Shee hath eſcap'd two Plagues, a luſtfull fool.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: I dare not challenge her I do confeſs,
As a reward due to my ſervice, and
If you deny her me, aſſure your ſelf
I'l never draw her from obedience:
I will not love her to procure her ruine,
And make m' affection prove her Enemy.

sp.speaker: Sr Tho.
sp.l: You ſpeak moſt honeſtly, I never did
Think ill of your intents, but alwaies gave
A teſtimony to your life as large
As were your merits. But your fortunes are
Unequal, there's the want.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: What's there defective
Love ſhall ſupply: True, Mr Credulous
Is a rich man, but yet wants that which makes
His riches uſefull, free diſcretion.
He may be ſomething in the Eye o'th' World;
But let a knowing man that can diſtinguiſh
Between Poſſeſſions, and good parts, but view him,
And prize impartially, he will be rated
Only as Cheſts, and Caskets, juſt according
To what he holds. I valew him, as I
Would an Exchequer, or a Magazine.
He is not vertuous, but well ſtor'd, a thing
Rather well victuall'd then well qualified.
And if you pleaſe to caſt your Eye on me,
Some moneys will call back my Fathers Lands
Out of his lime-twig fingers, and I ſhall
Come forth as gay as he.

sp.speaker: Sr Tho.
sp.l: I'l ſtrive no longer
For fear I ſeem t'oppoſe felicity.
If ſhee'l give her conſent y'are one.

sp.speaker: Jan.
sp.l: It is
The voice of Angels to me: I had thought
Nothing in all the ſtore of nature could
Have added to that love, wherewith I do
Reverence that name, my Father, till that you
Spoke this.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.l: I know your former Loves; grow up
Into an aged pair, yet ſtill ſeem young.
May you ſtand freſh, as in your Pictures ſtill,
And only have the reverence of the Aged.
I thank you for your pains Mr Conſtable,
You may diſmiſs your Watch now.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: A pox on't!
That after all this ne'r a man to carry
To Priſon? muſt poor Tradeſmen be brought out
And no body clap'd up?

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.l: That you mayn't want
Employment, friends take this I pray and drink it?

sp.speaker: Sli.
sp.l: Sir, when y'are cheated next we are your ſervants—

div.stage: Ex. all but Shape, Hear, Slic.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: LYe thou there Watchman; how the knave that's look'd for
May often lurck under the Officer!
Invention I applaud thee.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: London aire
Me thinks begins to be too hot for us.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: There is no longer tarrying here, let's ſwear
Fidelity to one another, and
So reſolve for New England.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: 'Tis but getting
A little Pigeon-hole reformed Ruff—

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: Forcing our Beards into th'Orthodox bent—

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Noſing a little Treaſon 'gainſt the King;
Bark ſomething at the Biſhops, and we ſhall
Be eaſily receiv'd.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: No fitter Place.
They are good ſilly People; Souls that will
Be cheated without trouble: One eye is
Put out with Zeal, th' other with Ignorance,
And yet they think they're Eagles.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: We are made
Juſt fit for that Meridian: no good work's
Allow'd there; Faith, Faith is that they call for,
And we will bring it 'em.

sp.speaker: Slic.
sp.l: What Language ſpeak they?

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.l: Engliſh, and now and then a Root or two
Of Hebrew, which wee'l learn of ſome Dutch Skipper
That goes along with us this Voyage; Now
We want but a good Wind, the Brethrens ſighs
Muſt fill our ſailes. For what old England won't
Afford, New England will. You ſhall hear of us
By the next Ship that comes for Proſelytes.
Each ſoyl is not the good mans Country only;
Nor is the lot his to be ſtill at home:
Wee'l claime a ſhare, and prove that Nature gave
This Boon, as to the good, ſo to the knave.

sp.speaker: Shap.
sp.l: VVE have eſcap'd the Law, but yet do feare
Something that's harder anſwer'd, your ſharp Eare.
O for a preſent ſlight now to beguile
That, and deceive you but of one good ſmile!
'Tis that muſt free us; th' Author dares not look
For that good fortune to be ſav'd by's Book.
To leave this bleſſed ſoyle is no great woe;
Our griefe's in leaving you, that make it ſo.
For if you ſhall call in thoſe Beames you lent,
'Twould ev'n at Home create a Baniſhment.
